title: Saundersfoot leads the way in launching new 'Climate Adaptation Toolkit'
bodyText:
A new 'Climate Adaptation Toolkit' has been launched to help Pembrokeshire communities prepare for the impacts of climate change, with the seaside village of Saundersfoot leading the way as the first to pilot the locally-led approach.

The Toolkit, developed by the Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum, brings together practical resources to help communities understand the risks they face - from coastal flooding to increased risk of wildfire - and to help communities work with key stakeholders to co-create their own local adaptation plans.

It includes free-to-access guides, templates, a network for action, and mapping tools designed to support place-based, community-led climate action.

"This is about turning concern into action,"said Tom Luddington, Coastal Stakeholder Manager at Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum.

"Coastal communities are on the frontline of climate change as sea levels rise, and we are seeing more intense storms, increased risk of wildfire, and heavier rain fall. The toolkit helps communities take the lead - because local knowledge, local leadership, and local collaboration are essential to building long-term resilience."

Saundersfoot leads the way in a pilot project starting earlier this year, with the seaside village becoming the first community to trial the toolkit.

Stakeholders including - residents, local businesses, landowners, Natural Resources Wales, The Crown Estate, Mid and West Wales Fire and Rescue Service, Pembrokeshire National Park Authority, Saundersfoot Harbour Authority and Pembrokeshire County Council all came together to assess flood risks, share knowledge, and begin co-creating a local climate adaptation strategy.

This collaborative process has already begun to influence how local partners work together.

County Councillor for the village's north ward, Cllr Alec Cormack described the pilot as "a good first step for how the Saundersfoot community can be more involved in co-creating climate adaptation plans - practical, inclusive, and with all the key stakeholders round the table."

County councillor for Saundersfoot's south ward Cllr Chris Williams said that he had attended the recent 'Community Climate Adaptation Planning Meeting' held at Saundersfoot Harbour, which discussed coastal erosion concerns.

Over the past couple of years, Saundersfoot Community Council has hosted 'Sustainable Coastal Communities' public meetings in collaboration with the Local Authority, to outline the challenges the seaside village will face in the future and to consider what actions may be possible to combat rising sea levels.

Feedback from residents has emphasized the need to balance short-term actions with long-term planning-potentially looking at many years ahead. Tourism has also been highlighted as a key part of the local economy, with the Strand playing a vital role in supporting this sector.

Also discussed has been the importance of improved shingle bank management, and sea defences, with the need to clarify permissions and responsibilities, especially with regard to private landowners, highlighted.

Following discussions at the most recent meeting last month, Cllr Williams provided a brief update with the aim to keep residents informed about the work being done in response to climate-related challenges in the coastal community.

He said that the key highlights from the meeting, included:

Emergency Response Focus Shift - "We heard from the Fire Officer, who explained the increasing need to focus on flood responserather than just fire. Emphasis was placed on pre-flood planning, community education, and reactive strategies to manage flood risks effectively."

The Crown Estate Engagement -"A representative from The Crown Estate (TCE), which owns approximately 50% of the land between the mean high and low water marks, spoke about how coastal erosion is changing land boundaries. It was encouraging to hear TCE's commitment to engage more directly with local communities."

Land Ownership Presentation - "A clear and informative presentation on land ownership was shared, helping those unfamiliar with the area to better understand property layouts and jurisdiction."

Action Planning and Priorities - "The group discussed short-term priorities, the potential to engage consultants for expert recommendations, and the exploration of long-term funding, possibly through grant-supported community adaptation projects."

Flood Defence Ideas - "Suggestions included improving the shingle bank and investigating how gabion basketsmight help protect vulnerable properties. All proposals must be aligned with nationalbiodiversity and net gain commitments.

Feasibility Study and Inclusion - "A feasibility study was proposed, with a strong emphasis on ensuring that residents and businesses on The Strand lead any conversation."

For the next steps, Cllr Williams said that the main working group will pause until September.

"In the meantime, Cllr Alec Cormack and I will continue to liaise with residents and business owners on The Strand and work towards coordinating a focused engagement group, ensuring all voices are heard and involved in shaping future action," he added.

Although Pembrokeshire focussed, the new toolkit has clear relevance across Wales and beyond. With more than 60% of the Welsh population living near the coast, and extreme weather events on the rise, the need for place-based planning has never been more urgent.

Link to Image

The Welsh Government's own risk assessments highlight flooding, coastal erosion, and loss of infrastructure as growing threats.

In response, the Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum's toolkit provides a scalable model that empowers communities to shape their own responses - while aligning with national policies like the Well-being of Future Generations Act and the Climate Adaptation Strategy for Wales launched in 2024.

WWF Cymru are funding the next stage of the project as part of their Wholescape Programme in Pembrokeshire.

Jessica McQuade, Programme Manager said: "This climate adaptation work in Saundersfoot offers a demonstration project of how we can tackle the triple challenge of climate change, nature loss and community wellbeing.

"The toolkit, and the wider Pembrokeshire Climate Adaptation Plan has the potential to show best practice to the rest of Wales but we need to fund and test its implementation. It is very important to be activity supporting communities to be resilient to climate change, taking a nature based approach where possible. We are really excited to be part of this project."

title: 270,000 awarded to climate adaptation projects in Cairngorms National Park
bodyText:
A NEW round of climate adaptation funding aimed at tackling the increasing risk of wildfires and weather extremes in the Cairngorms has been welcomed by local crofters and farmers.

They say the support is vital but caution that underlying land use issues also need to be addressed.

Twelve projects have been awarded funding through the Cairngorms National Park Authority-s 2025 Climate Adaptation Fund, with a total of 270,000 allocated to practical, on-the-ground climate solutions. These range from brush-clearing equipment to firefighting kits and sustainable land management initiatives.

The latest round attracted more than 60 expressions of interest and over 30 full applications, with the total value of proposed projects exceeding 1million. Launched in 2024, the fund has now awarded 640,000 to 30 projects.

Related Articles

Future Farming Investment Scheme sees 1500 applications in first week Over 3000 apply for Future Farming grants to boost farm productivity

Among the newly-funded schemes are a remote-controlled flail mower for wildfire prevention in Kingussie; collaborative resilience equipment for Alvie and Dalraddy Estates and the wider Badenoch and Strathspey area; firefighting and PPE for Dalnacardoch Estate; and a low ground pressure slurry tanker to recycle whisky waste in Grantown-on-Spey. The fund also supports solar panels and battery storage at a Grantown cafe and riparian tree planting along the River Spey as part of the Spey Riparian Collaboration.

Cabinet secretary for rural affairs, land reform and islands, Mairi Gougeon, said: -This fund empowers farmers, land managers and businesses to take meaningful steps to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

-In the wake of recent wildfires, it couldn-t be timelier to focus on practical equipment to help protect our precious landscapes.-

Convener of the Park Authority, Sandy Bremner added: -This funding underlines our absolute commitment to support people dealing with the practical challenges of a changing climate. The focus on wildfires builds on our wider initiatives, including the UK-s first integrated wildfire management plan and a proposed byelaw on recreational fires.-

But crofters and farmers say the challenge is only growing.

Robert MacDonald, chair of the Cairngorms Crofters and Farming Community, said the funding could not come at a more important time.

-I-d say it-s critical given how things have developed over the last few months,- he said. -We-re seeing big changes in land use across the National Park.

There-s more and more extensive rewilding and tree planting, taking over from the traditional farming and gamekeeping that used to happen on the estates.

-Because of that shift, fuel loading is going through the roof. Traditionally, practices like controlled muirburn kept heather and undergrowth in check. Now that those aren-t happening as much, the undergrowth is getting out of control.

-The fuel load has reached levels where the slightest spark can set things off - as we-ve unfortunately seen in recent weeks.- He added: -It-s also partly due to the lack of labour on estates these days. There just aren-t as many people working the land, so we need mechanised equipment to help tackle fires quickly, much quicker than we managed this year.-

Mr MacDonald said concern around wildfire was growing year-on-year, and pointed to the visual evidence around Dava as an example.

-It-s quite remarkable when you go out to places like Dava. You can see a clear difference between areas that are still grazed and those under rewilding schemes.

-Drive from one end to the other - on one side, you-ve got sheep grazing, and the fire hasn-t touched it. At the far end, where there-s no stock and it-s been rewilded, it-s all burnt and black.-

He added that community spirit remained strong in the area, particularly among traditional estates.

-I think it-s fair to say that traditional estates find it a lot easier to rally help,- he said. -Some estates that have gone down the rewilding route have let go of their gamekeepers and farm staff. That makes it harder to respond quickly when things go wrong.-

-In contrast, estates that still operate traditionally tend to have people around and can band together more easily when there-s an emergency like a wildfire.-

Asked whether this year-s funding total was enough, Mr MacDonald suggested money alone wasn-t the full answer.

-I think more consideration needs to be given to the wildfire risks that come with these changes in land use,- he said. -If the government is supporting rewilding and reforestation schemes, then fire safety must be a core part of that.

-Plans for these projects should have to include proper fire-breaks and access roads, so staff or volunteers can actually reach the source of a fire quickly.-

-It should be a condition of approval, not something that-s thought about after the fact. It needs to be built into the original planning of these schemes.-

Chief executive of the Park Authority, Grant Moir, said: -The ambition among farmers, land managers and businesses across the Park is clear.

These projects will deliver real and lasting impact, from enhancing wildfire resilience to supporting biodiversity, local jobs, and sustainable land use practices.-

Jamie Williamson, laird of Alvie and Dalraddy Estates, added: -Support from last year-s Fund allowed us to purchase vital fire suppression equipment, which proved crucial during the recent wildfires.

"This year-s funding will allow us to expand our capabilities further, with an all-terrain vehicle, fire fogging unit, and protective equipment that can be used across Badenoch and Strathspey.-

title: Why amphibious, wet environments hold the key to climate adaptation
bodyText:
As the planet braces for climate-change-induced fluctuations, the wisdom of communities living at the intersection of land and water could offer valuable lessons.

As the planet braces for climate-change-induced fluctuations, the wisdom of communities living at the intersection of land and water could offer valuable lessons.

People crossing the flooded Bagmati river, a branch of the Ganges, in Bihar, India.

Submergence at a river due to heavy monsoon rains in India with broken bridge and road and people walking in the water.

Credit: Joerg Boethling/Alamy

Why amphibious, wet environments hold the key to climate adaptation

Amphibious Anthropologies: Living in Wet EnvironmentsEdited by Alejandro Camargo, Luisa Cortesi and Franz Krause Univ. Washington Press (2025)

Coastal zones, river basins, marshes and other amphibious environments — where the boundaries between land and water are constantly redrawn —have always been places of shifting wetness. Climate change has deepened this instability, making the borders between wet and dry regions more erratic and unpredictable.

In Amphibious Anthropologies, nine essays explore these watery, in-between landscapes, offering insights from people who have long lived in the nebulous zones between land and water. These communities have learnt to adapt, to build sustainable futures in places where permanence is an illusion and where the ebb and flow of water is not a threat to be conquered, but a force to live with. The book is a guide for navigating a world in flux — taught by those who have always known that solid ground is not always solid.

Why farmers are beginning to take their government to court over climate change

Take the people living on the floodplains of northern Bihar, India. Accustomed to frequent flooding, they build circular embankments around their homes. The shapes of these embankments work with the flow of the water, encouraging it to go around them, rather than create sharp barriers that oppose the water. By contrast, the straight embankments introduced during British colonial rule in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries — and later replicated by democratically elected Indian governments — seek to confine and control the river. Such rigid structures often backfired: by presenting an unyielding barrier, they increase water pressure during floods, leading to dangerous breaches and widespread inundation.

The settings of the book’s essays — the floodplains in central India, the Fogliano wetlands in Italy, Jordan’s Dead Sea coastline, the Soomaa bogs in Estonia, the river valleys in the western United States, France’s alpine wetlands, the Colombian marshes, the tidal plains in the Bahamas and the Salton Sea in California — are wet environments that have been inhabited for centuries. These are places where wetness is an essential condition of life, and where human living is a process of “adaptation and respectful adjustment”.

Land and water

On the basis of insights from field studies and conversations with local inhabitants, 12 leading specialists in sociology, ecology and anthropology explore how governance, management and infrastructure decisions often fall short when guided by rigid binaries — such as wet and dry, alive and dead, beneficial and nuisance or natural and unnatural. These categories fail to capture the complexity of amphibious environments.

This is the case with the Salton Sea, California’s largest lake. Formed in the 1900s by flooding from the Colorado River, the lake has since been sustained by agricultural run-off from nearby farms irrigated by the river. But in the past few decades, water-transfer agreements to supply urban California have caused the lake to shrink year by year.

Wind blows toxic dust from the exposed lake bed towards the surrounding neighbourhoods, where asthma and other respiratory issues are prevalent at alarming rates. The shores are now strewn with the remains of dead birds and fish. This May, water finally began flowing into ponds in the southern region of the lake, part of the long-delayed Species Conservation Habitat Project, a ten-year effort to restore the habitat and improve its air quality. Although the project was announced in 2017, it stalled for years amid debates between local, state and federal officials over who should manage and restore the Salton Sea — and how.

A spring flood in Soomaa National Park in Estonia.

Spring flood in Soomaa National Park.

Credit: Focus/Toomas Tuul/UIG/ Getty

Historically, the lake has dried and filled up again over centuries. For some, this history means that the lake should be allowed to die because it is an artificial system. Others rightly point out the detrimental effects of such a move on the people, fish and migratory birds whose lives are enmeshed with the lake’s ecosystem.

“Over time, different understandings and interpretations of the Salton Sea’s identity — as wet or dry, natural or artificial, dead or alive — have played into the difficult management challenges that the lake faces,” writes political ecologist Alida Cantor in the opening essay of Amphibious Anthropologies. Focusing on what the lake does, not what it is, she says, can help to reframe debates about the lake’s management.

The book argues that we should look at the relationships that inhabitants have to a damp place to fully understand amphibious environments. Without this perspective, governments risk excluding the very communities they aim to support, argues anthropologist Sarah Wise in an essay set in Andros Island in the Bahamas.

To spur climate action, educators must get personal

The shoreline of Andros shifts with the tides. It is neither dry land or fluid sea. In 2002, the Bahamas government designated five protected areas on these tidal lands, which it saw as empty and unused mudflats. But islanders have long treated the area as a communal resource, relying on it for fishing, gathering medicinal plants and recreation. Children swim among mangroves at low tide, whereas high tide pushes people ashore and fishers to the sea. The 2002 restrictions threaten to cut off access, endangering both livelihoods and community ties.

“The model of enclosure conservation forces a rigid template for resource management and conservation: one that stands in stark contrast to the aquatic logic of between spaces in the Bahamas,” explains Wise. Instead, an effective form of governance needs to find a way to include “a multiplicity of voices, uses, perceptions, and claims to that space”.

For the most part, the book is easy to read, although some essays can be dense. It offers important insights for people involved in governance, policy or advocacy, particularly when dealing with ecosystems and communities that are vulnerable to the effects of climate change.

The essays help readers to move past imagining wet places as empty, difficult and harsh, or even romanticizing them as untouched wild lands, to seeing them as places where life struggles, adapts and is lived. The book presents insightful observations, conversations and case studies, showing the variety of forms that wet environments, and the life there, can take. It encourages readers to reject extreme binaries and imagine new ways of understanding the vibrant life in amphibious worlds.

title: Managing the inevitable: Tools for meeting the challenge of climate adaptation
bodyText:
Mitigation and adaptation are two complimentary facets of climate change action. It is essential to limit warming as much as possible, but also to adapt to changes already underway.
This is the current challenge for companies: to deploy a realistic and clear adaptation strategy based on trajectories while being ambitious on the mitigation strategy. To do everything they can to avoid the unmanageable and, at the same time, manage the inevitable.


Global warming impacts every aspect of a company
Under current climatic conditions, the increase in temperatures by 2100 is expected to reach between 2.2 and 3.4 degrees, well above the 2015 Paris Agreement temperature goal (between 1.5 and 2 degrees). Companies will be on the front line, as extreme weather events directly impact every link in a company's value chain, from physical infrastructure to business continuity to financial performance and even human resources. All sectors (tourism, energy, finance, etc.) are potentially affected, even those perceived as being exempt from material impacts, such as IT services.
However, companies sometimes find it difficult to define their adaptation strategy, given the variety and complexity of the variables that need to be taken into account.
The AXA Climate white paper enables companies to understand risk as a geographical concept, and to identify all the places in which they will have to implement their adaptation strategy. They must establish strong adaptation governance at every level, encouraging dialogue across departments and between different sites.
Risk assessments must follow a clear methodology; listing past events, their intensity, duration, and impact; relying on long-term climate projections - because the lifespan of a business activity can easily extend beyond 30 years, meaning today's forecasts may fall short; and finally, they must categorise the risks based on their level of priority for the organisation.
For each risk, businesses need to identify realistic measures to take - while making sure they involve the people directly affected. It's also essential to assess not just the economic feasibility, but also the organisational, technical, and regulatory aspects of each measure, to avoid the risk of maladaptation.
In taking these steps, an organisation can build an effective adaptation plan - one that implements progressive measures to remain agile in the face of unpredictable climate events.
Diagnosing the climate risks of their sites and infrastructures and then implementing operational solutions has already been put in place by large companies such as Michelin and Suez.
In addition, "nature-based" solutions, i.e. actions that aim to protect, sustainably manage and restore natural and modified ecosystems - while benefiting both human well-being and biodiversity, will pave the way for a good adaptation strategy: for example, the planting of rain gardens to promote soil permeability and fight against flooding, or planting vegetation in infrastructure to avoid heat exposure.
Concrete examples of good adaptation measures
What are example impacts by sector? Which professions are most exposed to which risks? How to carry out your diagnosis? What is the timescale? How can we take advantage of climate projections? What measures can be taken to avoid the risk of maladaptation?
These questions, among others, will be answered through the white paper and the course, "Adapting your organisation to a changing climate"
Testimonials from experts and professionals
The white paper and modules offer concrete examples of the impacts of climate change on organisations, and benefit from the expertise of several speakers, including Arnaud Vanon, expert in risk management, and Bertrand Pigeat, Group Audit Director & Risk Manager at Michelin, as well as Huu-An Pham, Director of Business Consulting, expert in climate adaptation at AXA Climate, and Estelle Rouhaud, adaptation project manager at Suez Consulting.
"The increase in extreme weather episodes in recent years marks the beginning of a growing awareness among companies, which we must support and develop. The path of adaptation is the most robust way to deal with the irreversibility of global warming - it takes into account the imperative of risk reduction, the maintenance of activities and the hope of a pathway to a regenerative model," says Huu-An Pham, Director of Business Consulting, expert in climate adaptation at AXA Climate.
For Antoine Poincaré, Vice-President of the AXA Climate School: "In France, we heard a lot of debates about adaptation last year: which scenario to choose, where to adapt first, how to avoid maladaptation, etc. For companies, the challenge involves combining a global, strategic vision with a very local vision of the issues. This requires the involvement of a wide variety of profiles on this subject: HR, site managers, etc... and our course responds to this need.
.

title: UK Government unveils research and innovation challenges for climate adaptation
bodyText:
Pictured: A flooded farm in Suffolk, 2021
For the first time, the two Government bodies have collaborated to identify priority areas in which research and innovation for climate adaptation needs to be advanced. A total of 11 have been listed:


Nature: Creating a natural environment resilient to climate impacts
Working land and seas: Making them sustainable and climate-resilient
Public health: Ensuring a healthy population in current and future climates
Buildings: Buildings should be fit for the future
Towns, cities and community preparedness
Food security: Food should be affordable, sustainable and high-quality now and in the future, whether it is produced within the UK or imported
Transport systems: Enhancing reliability and reducing emissions
Water supply: Safeguarding a plentiful water supply for people
Telecoms and ICT: Enhancing reliability and reducing emissions
Business and finance: A reliable supply of goods and services, and a stable financial system which enables adequate public and private investment in UK adaptation
The innovation and research gaps in each of these fields are summarised in the new Climate Adaptation Research and Innovation Framework (CARIF). The CARIF also explains how action in one field is likely to have a ripple effect on others; it notes that improving nature would have "direct implications" in all other areas, for example.
"Achieving climate resilience requires widespread action across governments, business, academia and civil society," the CARIF states. "It is not a singular issue but an interconnected systems challenge involving infrastructure, ecosystems, health, finance, data and governance."
Even if the UK achieves its targets to cut emissions, a certain level of physical climate change is already 'baked in' for the UK, with risks to become more severe and frequent in any emissions trajectory but the most severe impacts expected at levels exceeding the Paris Agreement's 1.5C and 2C trajectories.
The CCC  that all climate risks it measures for the UK have increased in urgency since 2016. It classes some 60% of the risks assessed as requiring the highest level or urgency.
Then, in late 2022,  due to a lack of responsibility for improving the climate resilience of critical infrastructure like power distribution networks, transport networks and communications infrastructure.
On the role of the CARIF in informing action, the Government's chief scientific advisor Professor Dame Angela McLean said: "We need new research to make the UK more resilient to climate change, and innovation to improve how effectively and affordably we ready systems for change.
"The UK has world-leading science capabilities which we can harness to ensure we are ready for future climate impacts."
. Industries set to receive a lion's share of the funding include space, life sciences and clean energy.
Updated CCC adaptation advice incoming
Environment Minister Emma Hardy added: "We are already seeing the impact of climate change and extreme weather on people's lives, from transport disruption to flooding in people's homes.
"This is why, alongside our research into climate adaptation, we are exploring how we can set out stronger objectives to drive action to increase our preparedness for the impacts of climate change up to and beyond the next National Adaptation Programme in 2028."
The CCC will release its next progress report to the UK Parliament on climate adaptation at the end of April. This should inform how the Government shapes the next National Adaptation Programme.
.
The High Court heard a legal challenge to the Programme from Friends of the Earth and two individuals - Kevin Jordan and Doug Paulley - last year. Jordan found himself after his house in Hemsby, Norfolk, succumbed to coastal erosion, while Paulley, managing multiple health conditions, faces heightened vulnerability.

title: Climate adaptation: Dozens of cities partner to improve urban resilience
bodyText:
Rio de Janeiro (pictured) is one of 22 participating cities
The partnership, with support from healthcare and health insurance giant Bupa and consumer goods major Reckitt, will allow the cities to share tools, insights, and technical support.


Topics covered will include the interlinked challenges of boosting urban climate resilience, reducing emissions and enhancing public health and wellbeing.
Resilient Cities, Reimagining Health
The partnership is called Resilient Cities, Reimagining Health. It brings together 22 cities from 15 countries, including Mexico, Brazil, England and the United States, collectively representing more than 100 million residents.
Cities confirmed to be taking part in the Community of Practice network include , Rio de Janeiro, Mexico City, Lagos, Glasgow, Sydney and Nairobi.
Central to the partnership is the Community of Practice collaborative platform, which is designed to accelerate action by enabling knowledge gathering and sharing. The platform has been created to  enhance the evidence base for the benefits of preventative solutions; develop and test tools for capacity-building within cities; pilot climate-sensitive and cost-effective public health interventions; and demonstrate the role that stakeholders can play in supporting city wellbeing.
.
Kris Licht, CEO of Reckitt and member of the Sustainable Markets Initiative Health Systems Task Force, stated: "As climate change intensifies public health challenges, adding pressure to health systems, with vulnerable and low-income communities being most affected, we need to rethink our approach to health, moving from a top-down, treatment-based model, to a more holistic one that emphasises keeping people well.
"Cities are on the front line of both climate change and public health. By aligning innovation and investment, this initiative is a critical step in building stronger, more equitable health systems and cities. It exemplifies the type of collaborative, cross-sectoral effort we need to create lasting impact at scale."

title: Quick View: Growing G20 Divisions Imply Headwinds To Climate Adaptation
bodyText: On 21 February, the first meeting of G20 foreign ministers during South Africa's G20 presidency concluded. US State Secretary Marco Rubio was notably absent, citing disagreement with South Africa’s land policies. This highlights the pushback which the G20 will face from the US government, with some elements of South Africa’s agenda likely to run into particular resistance from Washington, including boosting concessionary climate finance to low-income emerging markets and attracting investment into minerals processing (as opposed to boosting raw mineral exports). Longer-standing G20 issues such as boosting climate lending by multinational development banks (MDBs) could also face greater headwinds, particularly as the US will be taking over the G20 presidency from South Africa in December 2025.

title: Labour has made no progress on climate adaptation since gaining power, CCC claims
bodyText:
Labour has made no progress in addressing the risks of extreme weather caused by climate change since entering government, the Climate Change Committee (CCC) has said.

The government's statutory climate advisor called for more resources for climate adaptation planning as it warned the UK is still not appropriately prepared for an increase of heat waves, heavy rainfall and wildfires over the coming years.

Flooding shutterstock 2

One in four buildings could be at risk of flooding by 2050, according to the CCC report

The CCC's adaptation committee, which is required to report on the UK's progress on climate adaptation every two years, published its latest report today.

It said the "vast majority" of the assessment outcomes for the 2025 report share the same low scores as in 2023, with the committee finding "no evidence" to score a single outcome for adaptation delivery as "good".

"Notably, there has been no change in addressing this risk with the change in Government," the report added.

The report found 6.3 million properties in England are in areas at risk of flooding from rivers, the sea, and surface water, a number which is predicted to rise to around 8 million, or one in four, by 2050.

Over a third of railway and road kilometres are currently at flood risk, predicted to rise to around half by 2050, according to the report, with rail systems and power lines also at risk from extreme heat.

CCC chair Julia King said: "We have seen in the last couple of years that the country is not prepared for the impacts of climate change. We know there is worse to come, and we are not ready, indeed in many areas we are not even planning to be ready. The threat is greatest for the most vulnerable: we do not have resilient hospitals, schools, or care homes. Public and private institutions alike are unprepared.

"We can see our country changing before our eyes. People are having to cope with more regular extreme weather impacts. People are experiencing increasing food prices. People are worried about vulnerable family members during heatwaves.

"Ineffective and outdated ways of working within Government are holding back the country's ability to be future-fit. Is this Government going to face up to the reality of our situation? Failing to act will impact every family and every person in the country."

The report coincides with an intervention yesterday from Tony Blair, who has called for a new approach to net zero as he argued government policies on limiting fossil fuels were "doomed to fail".

The former prime minister said the debate on climate change had become "irrational" and people were no longer prepared to make financial sacrifices and changes in lifestyle that would have "minimal" effect on global emissions.

Blair also said in a report by the Tony Blair Institute that a backlash against net zero policies threatened to "derail the whole agenda" as global demand for fossil fuels and airline travel continues to increase over the next 20 years.

The report calls for more focus on emerging technologies such as carbon capture and storage and nuclear fusion, and a coordinated international effort to persuade the world's biggest economies, such as China and India, to cut their emissions.

Environment secretary Steve Reed said Blair had made "a valid and important contribution" to the climate change debate.

Speaking on Times Radio this morning, Reed said: "I agree with much of what he said, but not absolutely every word and dot and comma of it.

"But this government is moving to clean energy because it's best for Britain. It's more energy security for Britain."

Weather forecasters have predicted a spring heatwave in the UK, expected to peak tomorrow with temperatures of 29 degrees in London, could result in the hottest start to May on record.

title: UKGBC urges mandatory climate adaptation as UK marks hottest day of the year
bodyText:
Climate scientists say that human-driven climate change has made heatwaves significantly more frequent and intense.
surpassing the previous 2025 high of 33.2C recorded in Charlwood, Surrey on 21 June.
The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issued amber heat-health alerts across much of England, with warnings that high temperatures could impact public health services and the broader population.


The Met Office also confirmed that June 2025 was the warmest June on record in England, with an average temperature of 16.9C, surpassing the previous record set in 2023.
Analysis suggests that the heatwave affecting the UK last month was made up to 100 times more likely by global warming, with current conditions in south-east England estimated to be ten times more likely than in pre-industrial climates.
A call to action to embed adaptation measures in urban planning is one of the many recommendations in the UKGBC's new ', which outlines growing risks to homes, schools, hospitals and infrastructure from climate-related hazards including overheating, flooding, drought, wildfires and storms.
The roadmap warns that without systematic adaptation, many parts of the UK will face increased disruption from extreme weather events.
The cities and towns facing the highest climate exposure
The roadmap identifies thirteen locations across the UK as particularly vulnerable, including London, Birmingham, Manchester, Glasgow, Peterborough and Fairbourne.
It highlights that, under a global warming scenario of 2C above pre-industrial levels, schools in London and the South East could face up to 10 weeks of extreme heat annually, while care homes may experience indoor temperatures above 28C for as many as four weeks per year. Healthcare buildings in these regions are also projected to face repeated periods of overheating.
Additionally, UKGBC's modelling shows that six million homes in London and the South East are likely to experience more than two weeks of high heat exposure each year.
The report also warns that flooding could render places such as Peterborough and Fairbourne uninhabitable by the end of the century.
Recommendations to enhance climate resilience
The roadmap, developed over two years with input from Lloyds Banking Group, Zurich, Mace, Arup and others, introduces a four-stage framework for embedding resilience in built environment decision-making.
The stages are: be aware and educated, anticipate, prepare and adapt, and sustain resilience. Each stage sets out aims, goals and actions at both industry and policy levels, designed to ensure decisions are informed by the best available data.
It also calls for increased use of green infrastructure, such as trees, parks and water features, in urban development, and investment in a skilled workforce capable of delivering climate-resilient construction and design.
Government approach
Additionally, the report recommends the creation of an Office for Resilience in the Cabinet Office and the reinstatement of a Minister for Resilience.
The Government recently released its 10-Year Infrastructure Strategy
The Cabinet Office is set to conduct a review of resilience standards across 14 critical infrastructure sectors including energy, water, transport and digital and telecoms by 2026.
Following this assessment, the Government will analyse whether existing standards need to be updated or expanded. This decision will only be taken where there is clear evidence that current standards do not provide sufficient certainty or coverage. Any new or revised standards will be grounded in data, with analysis of their effectiveness, scope and the potential economic impact of additional interventions.
In the final stage, government departments will work with infrastructure operators to estimate the costs associated with maintaining these resilience standards in the future, particularly in light of increasing climate-related risks. The aim is to have new or strengthened standards in place across the key sectors by 2030. These standards will also help safeguard wider infrastructure, including hospitals, schools and data centres.
The Government is also considering setting more ambitious adaptation objectives in the next National Adaptation Programme, due in 2028, with resilience standards playing a key role in achieving those goals.

title: 'We are woefully underprepared': Green economy leaders react to CCC's climate adaptation report
bodyText:
Pictured: Past flooding in Old Malton, North Yorkshire
, published on Wednesday 30 April, warns policymakers that successive Governments have under-invested in adapting infrastructure, agriculture and healthcare systems to climate change, storing up increasing economic risk for the future.
Livelihoods, lives, food security and national security are at risk now, and these risks will increase in the future, the CCC warns.


Across the board, the CCC has classed one-quarter (26%) of outcomes as insufficient - the highest proportion to date. All outcomes related to health and wellbeing are, concerningly, classed as insufficient.
Influential individuals and groups across the UK's green economy are urging Ministers to heed the report's warnings and recommendations ahead of this summer's Spending Review presentation. Here, edie rounds up the reaction.
Simon McWhirtier, deputy chief executive at the UK Green Building Council:
"This report is a stark reminder that we are failing to respond to the devastating impacts of a changing climate, a choice that will cost lives and livelihoods.
"The CCC had previously likened our climate adaptation efforts to Cinderella, warning that adaptation is under-resourced, underfunded and often ignored. This new report shows little has changed.
"We welcome the CCC's clear calls for urgent, coordinated action across Government, and its emphasis on the built environment and community resilience, key themes addressed in the UK Climate Resilience Roadmap, which we are launching in June.
"As the risks from flooding, overheating, and extreme weather escalate, the need for long-term funding, better data, and a joined-up national strategy is critical. To truly meet the scale of the challenge, we must move beyond siloed approaches with systemic, cross-sector action that tackles the full range of climate risks and addresses the underlying vulnerabilities of our buildings and, as a result, communities."
Gareth Redmond-King, head of international programmes at the Energy & Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU):
"In a week of unseasonably high temperatures, , it is clear just how dangerous and costly climate change is becoming. These warnings, and the fragility of our global food systems, remind us we need to adapt to the heating we have already caused, and cut emissions fast if we want to avoid worse and more costly damage into the future.
"But the CCC's latest advice also reminds us of the UK's global leadership role, which includes investment through international climate finance, to support adaptation and protect those fragile food supply chains on which we rely so heavily.
"Just three years ago, , to the CCC's here: that we're adapting nowhere near fast enough. But they also found limits to our ability to adapt. Some ecosystems are already hitting those limits, even at 1.3C of heating."
Joe Dillon, policy advisor at E3G:
"The UK is now seeing devastating impacts from climate change. Lives, livelihoods and economic growth are at risk whilst political parties' action falls far behind public expectations.
"The Government must step up and - in collaboration with the private sector and civil society - develop a whole-of-economy plan for climate to protect local communities, businesses and the economy. Voter and business concern and appetite for action is high and will only grow as impacts worsen."
Bev Cornaby, director of the Corporate Leaders Group (CLG) UK:
"This report makes for sobering reading and shows the UK is not prepared for the impacts of climate change, which risk our health, well-being and economic prosperity. More worryingly, Government progress on adaptation has stalled or reversed in recent years, even as the effects of climate change become clearer.
"CLG UK welcomes the recommendations from the CCC, especially the need to improve objectives and targets. While business is responding to the commercial imperative to improve climate resilience across operations and supply chains, the interconnected nature of climate adaptation, with cascading and hard to predict risks and uncertainty over roles and responsibilities is slowing down delivery.
"The private sector can deliver more, including innovation, investment and leadership, with clear goals, joined up policy and better communication and engagement from Government."
Sarah Mukherjee, chief executive of the Institute of Environmental Management and Assessment (IEMA):
"The Government could take a useful step towards supporting climate adaptation across the whole economy by setting clear sector-specific guidance for businesses - which scenarios to plan for, how to improve coordination across departments, and how to tackle systemic risks and interdependencies head-on.
"For example, how many degrees of warming should businesses plan for?  And what do these scenarios mean in practice for their infrastructure, supply chains and the skill-set of their workforce?"
Bella O'Dowd, head of climate policy at WWF:
"We can all see how our climate is changing - when severe storms are forecast now, people in the six million homes at risk of flooding wonder whether to get the sandbags out rather than just take an umbrella.
"Successive UK Governments have left our country and communities woefully underprepared for the impacts of climate change. This is a wake-up call for all Government departments as delayed action only increases the costs. The evidence is clear: action on climate unlocks economic opportunities, improves our health and saves lives.  Farmers, communities and businesses can't afford any more delays."
Dr Maya Singer Hobbs, senior research fellow at the IPPR:
"The Committee could not be clearer: the effects of climate change will be severe, and successive Governments have not done enough to protect lives, livelihoods, and our economy, and resulted in higher costs of action today.
"It is time for a fundamental reset: this new Government has the opportunity to put climate resilience at the heart of its mission - protecting people now and in the future. v In a time of increasing uncertainty, this becomes more important.
"By baking resilience into the green energy mission, the plan to deliver 1.5 million homes, or in transport investments, the Government can deliver a safer, greener, fairer future, alongside growth, but this action must start today."
Signe Norberg, head of external affairs at the Aldersgate Group:
"These findings are a stark warning to the Government that there is an urgent need to act decisively to ensure that the UK is prepared for the impending impacts of climate change. They also reinforce the importance of doing this alongside ongoing mitigation efforts.
"This isn't just critical for our future health and wellbeing, it's fundamental to delivering long-term economic stability. Without decisive action, the UK will be faced with major disruption across all sectors of the economy, as well as vital public services, that will jeopardise growth and infrastructure projects.
"The Government must take these findings on board and deliver a cohesive adaptation plan to prepare for the impacts of climate change. As outlined by the Committee, this should be properly resourced and bring together all relevant departments and policy areas to ensure it has maximum impact. A proactive approach now is needed to protect our people, homes and businesses."
Sophie O'Connell, senior policy adviser at Green Alliance:
"Climate change is already here, and everyone is feeling the heat. But it's alarming that plans to protect our health are limited and progress is insufficient, because the people whose health is most at risk from extreme heat are also least able to adapt to it. This should be a wake-up call for the Government, which needs a strategy for making our existing homes ready for extreme heat. Building regulations must also specify that new homes are built to be cool."
Patrick Begg, director of outdoors and resources at the National Trust:
"With the UK , today's warning from the CCC mustn't be ignored. Climate adaptation should be a cross-Government priority, encompassing everything from health and the environment to transport and housing.
"At the National Trust, we estimate 70% of the places we look after will be at a medium to high risk of climate hazards by 2060, including from floods, droughts, and rising seas. Without concerted action, the UK's cultural and natural landscapes and heritage could be changed beyond repair.
"The good news is that taking action on climate change is incredibly popular; a recent study suggests that want their government to do more to fight global heating."
Ali Plummer, director of policy & advocacy at Wildlife and Countryside Link:
"Climate adaptation isn't optional - it is a fundamental necessity for a safe, thriving future.
"It is a failing of current policies and successive Governments that the UK is so poorly prepared for the extreme weather already exhausting communities, emergency services, and local economies. This Government must recognise the critical role that nature plays in in building resilient, healthy, and vibrant communities able to withstand and adapt to the real impacts of climate change.
"A nature-positive planning system must be part of the solution. We need planning that embeds nature recovery, green infrastructure, and long-term resilience at its heart. Weakening protections and sidelining ecological expertise will only leave communities more exposed to extreme weather, food insecurity, and ecosystem collapse. Extreme weather will also cause more nature damage from drought and wildfires."
Tom Lancaster, head of land, food and farming at the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU):
"Climate change is having a devastating and multifaceted impact on UK farming and our collective food security.
"The response to this scale of risk is clearly not aligned to the jeopardy it poses, and yet, we have solutions available now, including . Investing in these schemes at the spending review in June will be needed to build the resilience of UK food production, and will be a key test of whether the Government has taken the criticisms in this report on board."
Roger Mortlock, chief executive of CPRE:
"This report is a clarion call to think differently about land. It supports CPRE's evidence that most productive agricultural land is at high risk of flooding and research from this year that shows that farms around our towns and cities are vanishing at an alarming rate. We need to safeguard our remaining farmland to boost biodiversity and ensure the UK's food security.
"Making the best use of our finite supply of land means taking a smarter approach to renewables, infrastructure and housing. If agricultural land is as precious as this report demonstrates, we can't afford to keep wasting these opportunities to put solar on roofs, not prime farmland.
"Likewise, the default for building new homes is too often a needless take of agricultural land, while opportunities to develop 1.2 million homes on brownfield sites are ignored. This report urges a rethink on how the Government delivers its targets and a recognition that land might be our most precious resource in adapting to climate change."
The Soil Association's policy director Brendan Costelloe:
The Government needs to take urgent action if it is going to rescue our climate, nature and future food resilience.
"We know that intensive farming, which depends on fossil-fuel-based fertilisers, is causing climate change whilst also being more vulnerable to its effects, which threatens our environment and our food security. We therefore need to see a rapid, system-wide transition to agroecological farming practices, such as organic, which reduce the environmental impact and not only secure our food system for the future but also secure the natural world too.
"We have more farmers than ever wanting to transition to organic, so it's vital that the Government restores support that was frozen recently alongside other SFI payments, so farmers can begin that journey immediately.
"More broadly, the Government needs to reinstate all the SFI schemes that have been correctly targeted at improving soil quality, like cover crops and herbal leys. Improving soil quality is probably the most important thing farmers can do to protect themselves from floods and droughts, and deliver a climate-resilient food system."
Published 30th April 2025

title: The adaptation imperative
bodyText:
Link to Image

The impacts of climate change are no longer long-term threats but present-day challenges that buildings, communities and infrastructure are already facing. JLL estimates $340bn (£249bn) of global real estate assets will be at risk from climate-related events by 2050, with that figure potentially rising to more than $1tn if significant adaptation measures are not implemented.

Climate adaptation is driving financial decisions in the market. Physical climate risks and resilience are now key parameters for investors during their due diligence processes. Insurance markets are also responding with reduced coverage and higher premiums for vulnerable properties, creating financial pressures for property owners who have not invested in resilience measures.

In response, regulatory frameworks are evolving, with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures mandating transparency around physical climate risks and the EU Taxonomy’s climate adaptation objectives creating clearer standards for effective climate adaptation in real estate. UK regulations currently deal with physical climate risks at a local level, so planning requirements relating to hazards such as flooding and overheating risk can only be inconsistent.

Climate adaptation vs mitigation

The real estate industry has historically focused predominantly on transition risks and climate mitigation strategies, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through energy efficiency improvements, renewable energy adoption and low-carbon construction strategies. While these efforts remain essential, they address only half of the climate challenge. Assuming that 80% of the building stock in 2050 will already exist now, we need to understand how vulnerable standing assets are against the changing climate and develop robust adaptation strategies. However, climate adaptation – preparing buildings to withstand and recover from climate impacts – has received less attention compared to climate mitigation, despite its growing urgency.

The relationship between adaptation and mitigation efforts creates both synergies and potential conflicts. Green roofs exemplify positive synergy, providing cooling effects (adaptation) while reducing energy consumption (mitigation). Similarly, passive design strategies can enhance thermal comfort during extreme weather while reducing operational emissions. Nature-based solutions can also enhance resilience and they often require less capital expenditure compared to other retrofit measures and can unlock wider benefits enhancing ecology and biodiversity.

title: Toolkit to help Pembrokeshire communities prepare for climate change
bodyText:
A new Climate Adaptation Toolkit has been launched to help Pembrokeshire communities prepare for the impacts of climate change.

The seaside village of Saundersfoot is the first to trial this locally-led approach.

The toolkit, developed by the Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum, provides practical resources to help communities understand the risks they face, including coastal flooding and wildfire threats.

It also assists in the creation of local adaptation plans.

Tom Luddington, coastal stakeholder manager at Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum, said: "This is about turning concern into action.

"The toolkit helps communities take the lead - because local knowledge, local leadership, and local collaboration are essential to building long-term resilience."

The pilot project in Saundersfoot included stakeholders such as residents, local businesses, landowners, and various authorities.

They assessed flood risks, shared knowledge, and began co-creating a local climate adaptation strategy.

Councillor Alec Cormack described it as "a good first step for how the Saundersfoot community can be more involved in co-creating climate adaptation plans."

The toolkit, while Pembrokeshire-focused, has relevance across Wales and beyond, given the increasing extreme weather events and the majority of the Welsh population living near the coast.

The Welsh Government's risk assessments highlight the growing threats of flooding, coastal erosion, and infrastructure loss.

WWF Cymru is funding the next stage of the project as part of their Wholescape Programme in Pembrokeshire.

The full Climate Adaptation Toolkit is divided into four sections: Learning Hub, Community Action, Network for Action, and Resources.

Following positive feedback from the Saundersfoot pilot, Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum plans to extend the toolkit's rollout to more areas.

The team is inviting partnerships with local authorities, town and community councils, and environmental organisations across Wales to adopt and adapt the model to their own needs.

The Climate Adaptation Toolkit is free to access on the Pembrokeshire Coastal Forum's website.

title: National park funds for army of workers to tackle wildfires
bodyText:
The country's largest national park is to help fund a growing army of rural workers to help tackle wildfires.

The Cairngorms National Park Authority (CNPA) has confirmed that 12 projects will share a £270,000 fund to tackle the impacts of climate change.

Money from last year's Climate Adaptation Fund bought fire-fighting equipment used to control and extinguish the largest wildfire in Scotland's history at Dava in Moray last month.

When fires broke out in July, more than 100 workers from dozens of private businesses were used to help tackle the blazes.

Scottish Land and Estates (SLE) estimated they were the largest wildfires Scotland had ever witnessed, covering more than 29,000 hectares.

This year's fund attracted more than 60 expressions of interest and more than 30 full applications.

The total value of proposed projects exceeded £1 million, highlighting the desire from farmers, land managers, business and community groups to contribute to climate action across the national park.

The 12 successful projects include: ? A remote-controlled track flail mower to reduce the height of brush, helping reduce wildfire risk in Kingussie.

? Equipment and collaboration to enhance wildfire resilience across Badenoch and Strathspey and further afield at Alvie and Dalraddy estates.

?Fire-fighting equipment, personal protection equipment and fire prevention equipment including hand-cutting tools for building wildfire resilience at Dalnacardoch.

Mairi Gougeon, Cabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs, Land Reform and Islands, said: "This fund is the latest example of the vital, hands-on role our national parks play in helping local communities meet environmental and climate-related challenges head-on.

"It empowers farmers, land managers and businesses to take meaningful steps to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

"These projects will deliver swift and practical benefits to those striving to safeguard their livelihoods and support restoration efforts in the Cairngorms National Park."

The Climate Adaptation Fund first launched in 2024 to support capital works and investments in response to the environmental challenges in the wake of climate change. Together with this year's fund, £640,000 has now been awarded to 30 recipients in the national park.

Sandy Bremner, convener of the Cairngorms National Park Authority, said: "This funding underlines the national park's absolute commitment to support people dealing with the practical challenges of a changing climate.

"It will also help to tackle threats to lives, livelihoods and our natural heritage across the region."

title: One neighbourhood in the Forest of Dean at risk of dangerous heatwaves - as map reveals heatwave hotspots across England
bodyText:
One neighbourhood in the Forest of Dean is at risk of dangerous heatwaves, new research suggests.

Environmental charity Friends of the Earth analysed 2022 heatwave data, when temperatures rose above 40C, alongside data on the number of older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients to reveal which areas across England are at risk from future heatwaves.

As hotter weather hits the UK this week, the charity called on the Government to take "urgent action to protect those most under threat".

The research shows Dymock, Hartpury and Huntley in the Forest of Dean was considered a "high heat" area, meaning it experienced the hottest temperatures in 2022 and is likely to be exposed to future heatwaves.

Across the country, the charity identified 4,715high heat neighbourhoods. It included 1,920 at an enhanced risk of health impacts due to a combination of factors, such as a lack of green space, an older population, and low income.

Friends of the Earth campaigner, Denis Fernando, said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all - but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients."

He added: "The Government must urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms - as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

The analysis also found 9,589 care or nursing homes, 1,012 hospitals and 10,064 nurseries are in high heat neighbourhoods.

It included six care homes and two nurseries in the Forest of Dean.

In July, Friends of the Earth and two people impacted by the climate crisis filed an official complaint with the European Court of Human Rights over the UK Government's climate adaptation programme.

The group said the Government's plans and policies for protecting communities from the impacts of climate change are "inadequate".

One of the co-claimants is disability rights activistDoug Paulley, a care home resident in West Yorkshire, who has health conditions which are exacerbated by hot temperatures.

Mr Paulley said: "Time and again, disabled people are treated as an expendable afterthought in emergencies - and climate change is one of the biggest.

"The Government's lack of effective consideration for us in its climate action plan is completely unacceptable."

A Government spokesperson said: "Alongside becoming a clean energy superpower, the Government is taking robust action to adapt to a changing climate.

"The National Adaptation Programme includes steps to make local communities become more resilient to overheating, a Local Advisory Climate Service to give authorities support and we're putting £30 billion into improving hospital buildings.

"We urge people to take extra care in the hot weather with building regulations in place to reduce the risk of new homes overheating and housing tenants can speak to their council if excess heat means that their property is in a dangerous condition."

title: -Bam - AM and Amvest acquire former Draka site in Amsterdam North
bodyText:
Area developers AM (a subsidiary of Royal BAM Group) and Amvest have acquired the former Draka site in Amsterdam North from Prysmian, Hines and Provast.

The 50,000 m-2 site provides space for approximately 150,000 m-2 of gross floor area to be developed.



Over the coming years, a vibrant new urban district will be created, offering plenty of space to live, work, and relax. The acquisition of the Draka site ranks among the largest development land purchases in the Netherlands in recent years. 1,600 homes - two-thirds affordable

The ambitious plans include the construction of around 1,600 new homes on the five-hectare site, two-thirds of which will be offered at below-market rates. Additionally, some 30,000 m-2 is earmarked for light industry, office space, and hospitality. The area is situated directly on the IJ, with views over Java Island. Water and nature will play a central role in the design, enhancing both quality of life and climate adaptation.

Future-proof and nature-inclusive

AM and Amvest aim to create a future-proof, inclusive neighbourhood that complements the dynamics of the wider Hamerkwartier. The design will emphasise climate adaptation, nature-inclusive building and a balanced mix of residential, work and communal spaces.

Quality and affordability

Ronald Huikeshoven, Chairman of AM's board, said: 'With the purchase of this area we are once again investing in the future of Amsterdam and contributing to the urgent housing challenge. On this beautifully located site, we want to create a sustainable, high-quality residential environment. We are committed to quality, affordability and a careful integration into the character of the area. Together with our partners, we intend to develop a new neighbourhood here that will be of real value to current and future generations.'

Implementation timeline

Demolition is expected to commence at the end of this year, followed by environmental remediation. The development will be carried out in phases, with construction due to begin in 2027 once the zoning plan is approved. The site has been fenced off for over a decade; during redevelopment, AM and Amvest plan to reopen it to the public, even while construction is underway.

title: Cairngorms National Park Authority's climate change package for land managers
bodyText:
Farmers, land managers and businesses will share a £270,000 pay-out from the Cairngorms National Park to help them adapt to the changing climate.

The recipients of the park's 2025 Climate Adaptation Fund were announced yesterday (Wednesday). The awards will go towards practical, on-the-ground solutions to help tackle and mitigate the effects of climate change - including responding to wildfires.

"This year's fund attracted over 60 expressions of interest and more than 30 full applications," a CNPA spokesperson confirmed. "The total value of proposed projects exceeded £1 million, highlighting the desire from farmers, land managers, business and community groups to contribute to climate action across the national park."

The 12 successful projects include: a remote-controlled track flail mower to reduce the height of brush, helping reduce wildfire risk in Kingussie; equipment and collaboration to enhance wildfire resilience across Badenoch and Strathspey and further afield at Alvie and Dalraddy Estates; firefighting equipment, personal protection equipment and fire prevention equipment including hand cutting tools for building wildfire resilience at Dalnacardoch.

Also funded will be a low ground pressure slurry tank to use the waste product from the whisky industry as fertiliser in Grantown, and installation of solar panels and battery storage solution at Scrumpy's coffee shop in the Strathspey capital.

Money will go towards the planting of riparian trees along the upper River Spey by the Spey Riparian Collaboration.

Mairi Gougeon, rural affairs secretary, said: "This fund is the latest example of the vital, hands-on role our national parks play in helping local communities meet environmental and climate-related challenges head on. It empowers farmers, land managers and businesses to take meaningful steps to mitigate the impacts of climate change. In the wake of the recent wildfires, it couldn't be timelier to focus on practical equipment to help fight fires on our precious landscape. These projects will deliver swift and practical benefits to those striving to safeguard their livelihoods and support restoration efforts in the Cairngorms National Park."

The Climate Adaptation Fund first launched in 2024 to support capital works and investments in response to the environmental challenges we're facing in the wake of climate change. Together with this year's fund, £640,000 has now been awarded to 30 recipients in the National Park. The fund aligns with the Cairngorms National Park Partnership Plan 2022-2027. Projects needed to demonstrate that they fit with the Plan's priorities and contribute to the delivery of the Scottish Government's National Climate Change Adaptation Programme.

Sandy Bremner, Convener of the Cairngorms National Park Authority, said: "This funding underlines the National Park's absolute commitment to support people dealing with the practical challenges of a changing climate. It will help to tackle threats to lives, livelihoods and our natural heritage. The focus on wildfires builds on our wider initiatives, from the UK's first integrated wildfire management plan to the widely supported byelaw on recreational fires, now awaiting Scottish Government approval."

In submitting projects for the fund, applicants were encouraged to deliver economic benefits through local employment and enterprise. In addition, applicants were asked to consider nature-based solutions, with the Park Authority prioritising projects that promote habitat and species recovery.

Grant Moir, the park authority's CEO, said: "The scale of the ambition among farmers, land managers and businesses to act to mitigate the effects of climate change is clear. These 12 projects will have a real and lasting impact and will support efforts to adapt to the changing climate - particularly devastating wildfires experienced in and close to the National Park in recent weeks - while supporting biodiversity enhancement, local jobs and sustainable land use practices."

Jamie Williamson, Laird at Alvie and Dalraddy Estates, said: "The support we received from last year's Climate Adaptation Fund went towards the purchase of fire suppression equipment. This included a trailer-mounted fire fogging unit and a slurry tanker adapted for tackling wildfires with a rain gun to extinguish fires at a distance and with the ability to supply water to replenish fire fogging units with limited water carrying capacity. Our estate team supported the efforts of the fire service and other local estates in tackling the recent wildfires, using this equipment.

"We are pleased to have received further support from this year's fund which will go towards purchasing an all-terrain vehicle equipped with a fire fogging unit, a backpack blower, radios and firefighting PPE including overalls, gloves and masks. This equipment could also be used across Badenoch and Strathspey and further afield if needed."

title: 'At risk' areas revealed in Colchester's climate adaptation report
bodyText:
A MAJOR climate change report has been published by Colchester council, with heatwaves and flooding predicted to become more frequent in years to come.

City leaders declared a climate emergency back in 2019 and committed to becoming carbon neutral as an organisation by 2030.

The council commissioned a report which includes climatic projections for Colchester and reflects on how the region has been affected in recent years.

The report said in the years until 2030, Colchester could experience temperature rises of 1 C annually compared to 1990 levels.

Alternative models show temperatures could increase by up to five degrees in summer.

The potential for heatwaves is likely to increase.

Data shows there are five days on average above 25 C per summer month between 1991 to 2019.

This is predicted to increase to 19 days on average in the years from 2041 to 2070.

Prediction - Area of North Essex that are projected to be under the annual flood level by 2050 (Image: Colchester Council)

According to the UK Climate Risk Indicator Explorer, Essex is the second-most at risk county for wildfires in the UK.

Essex is also still classed as a severely water stressed area and the average water use in the county is 155 to 160 litres per person per day - far above the UK average of 144 litres.

The report also said Climate Central predicts many areas of Colchester will be below the annual flood level - areas which statistically flood every year on average.

This includes much of Mersea Island, parts of Wivenhoe and Rowhedge, and urban areas along the River Colne due to rises in sea levels.

The report said the overall time for which the Strood will be impassable to vehicles will likely increase which will impact access to Mersea island.

A spokesman for Colchester Council said: -Climate change is already impacting our city - through extreme heat, flooding, and drought - and these risks are only set to grow.

-That-s why Colchester joined a national Defra-led pilot to assess how local authorities can better adapt services and planning in response.

"This report marks the beginning of a more coordinated, long-term approach to adapting Colchester for the future.-

Despite the concerns, Anglian Water has said it does not expect to enforce a hosepipe ban this summer.

A spokesman said: -We know the East of England is set to see wetter winters and drier summers as climate change progresses, and that Colchester will be especially hard hit.

-That-s why we-re working hard to make sure our water and sewerage infrastructure in the area is ready to adapt to climate change, so we can keep our customers- taps flowing and toilets flushing for years to come, as Essex-s population is set to grow at 10 per cent by 2043.-

The spokesman said this year-s reservoir levels were -very good- meaning they do not expect any temporary usage bans or hosepipe bans this summer.

Anglian Water will also be building a 100million reuse site called the Colchester advanced water recycling which will begin construction next year with a demonstration centre.

New reservoirs and pipelines to move water from the wetter parts of our region to the drier areas, including Essex, will also be made,

More smart meters will also be installed to reduce water usage.

The spokesman also said there was the additional risk of flooding and Anglian Water will be upgrading their storm storage at several of their water recycling centres in Essex as well as install -new state-of-the-art- sewer monitors on their network.

Castle ward councillor Mark Goacher said it is important for future generations that climate change is addressed.

Concerned - Mark Goacher said southeast England was at particular risk of water scarcity due to the rising population and lack of adequate infrastructure to support it (Image: Steve Brading) He said: -First of all, it is very important for all councils to do these reports as this will seriously affect people-s lives for a long period of time - particularly people who live on coastal areas with the risk of flooding, as well as weather changes and risk of flooding.

-I am very aware there is a feeling that, as this is such a big issue, the approach should be that we bury our heads in the sand - in the general public there is that attitude and we need to do work like this to show the potential risk.-

Mr Goacher said that the report was important -irrespective- of whether you believe climate change is man-made or natural as it is a -risk-assessment- for the region.

He added water scarcity impacts the southeast of England harder because infrastructure has not grown in line with the population increase.

He said: -The challenge with the climate change mitigation movement is to make sure it does not mean 'impoverishing the average person'.

-We need to get the funding from those who have the broadest shoulders.-

title: One neighbourhood in the Forest of Dean at risk of dangerous heatwaves - as map reveals heatwave hotspots across England
bodyText:
One neighbourhood in the Forest of Dean is at risk of dangerous heatwaves, new research suggests.

Environmental charity Friends of the Earth analysed 2022 heatwave data, when temperatures rose above 40C, alongside data on the number of older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients to reveal which areas across England are at risk from future heatwaves.

As hotter weather hits the UK this week, the charity called on the Government to take "urgent action to protect those most under threat".

The research shows Dymock, Hartpury and Huntley in the Forest of Dean was considered a "high heat" area, meaning it experienced the hottest temperatures in 2022 and is likely to be exposed to future heatwaves.

Across the country, the charity identified 4,715high heat neighbourhoods. It included 1,920 at an enhanced risk of health impacts due to a combination of factors, such as a lack of green space, an older population, and low income.

Friends of the Earth campaigner, Denis Fernando, said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all - but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients."

He added: "The Government must urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms - as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

The analysis also found 9,589 care or nursing homes, 1,012 hospitals and 10,064 nurseries are in high heat neighbourhoods.

It included six care homes and two nurseries in the Forest of Dean.

In July, Friends of the Earth and two people impacted by the climate crisis filed an official complaint with the European Court of Human Rights over the UK Government's climate adaptation programme.

The group said the Government's plans and policies for protecting communities from the impacts of climate change are "inadequate".

One of the co-claimants is disability rights activistDoug Paulley, a care home resident in West Yorkshire, who has health conditions which are exacerbated by hot temperatures.

Mr Paulley said: "Time and again, disabled people are treated as an expendable afterthought in emergencies - and climate change is one of the biggest.

"The Government's lack of effective consideration for us in its climate action plan is completely unacceptable."

A Government spokesperson said: "Alongside becoming a clean energy superpower, the Government is taking robust action to adapt to a changing climate.

"The National Adaptation Programme includes steps to make local communities become more resilient to overheating, a Local Advisory Climate Service to give authorities support and we're putting £30 billion into improving hospital buildings.

"We urge people to take extra care in the hot weather with building regulations in place to reduce the risk of new homes overheating and housing tenants can speak to their council if excess heat means that their property is in a dangerous condition."
