title: ADB, United Nations Partner to Develop Climate Insurance for Fiji Businesses
bodyText:
SUVA, FIJI - The Asian Development Bank (ADB), the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF), and the UN Development Programme (UNDP) will help create an insurance market for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Fiji that are increasingly threatened by extreme weather.



Supported by $ 950,000 in technical assistance from the Asia-Pacific Climate Finance Fund (ACliFF), the initiative will research the insurance landscape for small businesses in Fiji, and work with local insurance providers to develop and test pilot products. The initiative builds on the work of the Pacific Insurance and Climate Adaptation Programme (PICAP), which provides parametric insurance to vulnerable communities in the Pacific.

"With small businesses making up such a significant proportion of the Fijian economy and workforce, it is essential to protect this sector," said ADB's Pacific Subregional Office Regional Director Aaron Batten. "This initiative will help lay the foundation for a domestic insurance market specifically designed to meet the needs of these businesses and support climate resilience across critical sectors of the Fijian economy."

Parametric insurance is a form of index-based insurance that pays out when pre-agreed trigger conditions are met, such as rainfall thresholds or wind speeds. With simple rules and pre-approval-there's no need to prove actual losses-parametric insurance can help insulate vulnerable communities from climate hazards by providing fast, pre-defined payouts.

MSMEs account for more than 80% of Fijian businesses and employ more than a quarter of the workforce, according to the Fiji Bureau of Statistics. But the sector remains highly vulnerable to extreme weather, with limited access to tailored insurance solutions that can support recovery and build resilience.

ADB's Country Partnership Strategy for Fiji for 2024-2028 supports the country's resilience to economic and climate-related shocks, and is aligned with the objectives of PICAP to build the financial preparedness of low-income households against natural hazards. PICAP is jointly implemented by UNCDF, UNDP, and the UN University's Institute for Environment and Human Security.

"This innovative approach empowers MSMEs in the world's toughest economies to flourish, strengthen resilience, and foster sustainable development that uplifts communities and leaves no one behind," said UNCDF Executive Secretary Pradeep Kurukulasuriya.

"UNDP is proud to partner in strengthening the resilience of MSMEs," said UNDP Resident Representative for the Pacific Office in Fiji Munkhtuya Altangerel. "This initiative supports our broader efforts across the Pacific to promote risk-informed development, harness digital innovation, and accelerate progress."

ACliFF is a multi-donor trust fund established in April 2017. It seeks to support the development and implementation of financial risk management products that can help unlock capital for climate investments and improve resilience to climate impacts.

ADB is a leading multilateral development bank supporting inclusive, resilient, and sustainable growth across Asia and the Pacific. Working with its members and partners to solve complex challenges together, ADB harnesses innovative financial tools and strategic partnerships to transform lives, build quality infrastructure, and safeguard our planet. Founded in 1966, ADB is owned by 69 members-50 from the region.

title: Schneider Electric and Women Action Sustainability (WAS) Launch New Report on Climate Adaptation to Build Resilience
bodyText:
December 2, 2024

* Nearly 40% of companies surveyed for this study have developed climate adaptation plans, yet only 6% have fully implemented adaptation measures.

* This report includes recommendations for large enterprises, the financial sector, and public administration to effectively plan and implement climate adaptation actions to ensure the resilience of businesses and communities amid the climate crisis.



Schneider Electric, the leader in the digital transformation of energy management and automation, has collaborated with Women Action Sustainability (WAS), a non-profit association that promotes sustainability among companies, institutions and society, to publish a new report entitled, "Creating Sustainable Impact: Building Resilience Through Climate Adaptation". This report highlights the interdependencies between public and private stakeholders and the collective responsibility required to drive actions to build resilience amidst escalating climate change impacts.

"At Schneider Electric, we recognize the vital importance of integrating climate risk and adaptation strategies to enhance the resilience of businesses," said Steve Wilhite, President, Schneider Electric Sustainability Business. "Climate change is impacting many companies financially, not only with destruction of physical assets but also due to higher interest and insurance rates. Schneider Electric is dedicated to pushing the boundaries of climate progress, collaborating with our network to integrate sustainable practices throughout our ecosystem."

This report highlights how businesses from various industries and regions are addressing climate-related risks with adaptation strategies and identifies market opportunities and gaps that require attention. The following are several key findings from this report:

* 38% of companies have developed clear climate adaptation plans, however, only 6% have fully implemented outlined adaptation measures.

* Only 12% have detailed methods to quantify the financial impact of physical climate risks.

* Many have experienced climate-related impacts on their supply chains (30%) and on direct operations (28%).

* 30% of companies surveyed do not have insurance coverage to mitigate financial risks linked to climate hazards.

Climate risk is broadly recognized as a financial risk and is expected to have a significant impact on corporate profit and loss statements. The United Nations reports that extreme weather events have led to $ 4 trillion in losses over the past 50 years. With the global temperature escalating, the frequency and severity of climate-related disasters are projected to rise annually, reinforcing the urgency to develop climate adaptation plans and actions. In the UNEP's Adaptation Gap Report 2024, the finance adaptation gap is estimated to be between $ 194-366 billion USD per year, which is a factor for the lag in adaptation planning and implementation efforts.

"Adaptation is highlighted as a major emerging trend, given the increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, and corporations are experiencing the impacts of climate change," said Mónica Chao, President, Women Action Sustainability. "We aim to inspire action in climate adaptation at the corporate level. We invite not only corporations, but all stakeholders, including policymakers, financial institutions, and insurers, to engage in collaboration to drive and enable action."

The report highlights that, while businesses around the world are showing efforts to mitigate their impact on the environment, current ways of operating will need to change to ensure the resilience of activities. This transformation requires investment. The involvement of the banking and financial services sector is key to support companies in the process of implementing their adaptation plans. WAS wants to call on public administration and scientists, also at the global level, to help companies on this path by providing guidance, tools and resources as needed.

Ana Peña, President of Women Action Sustainability's Climate Change Group, adds, "in a world where demands and conditions change rapidly, accelerating infrastructure adaptation strategies is crucial to ensure resilience and efficiency. The ability to anticipate and respond agilely to new challenges and opportunities ensures that infrastructures not only support the present but are also prepared for the future."

This report offers strategic recommendations to help corporations mobilize action, while emphasizing the critical roles of the financial sector, which serves as a catalyst for change, and public administration in facilitating climate adaptation planning. This report also addresses the need for businesses to not only adapt current physical assets, but also proactively design future physical assets to be more resilient and capable of withstanding the impacts of climate change.

Download the full report here.

About Women Action Sustainability

Women Action Sustainability is a non-profit association, made up of more than 200 women managers, whose goal is to ensure that sustainability is present at the tables where decisions are made at the highest level. Thus, through female leadership, WAS calls on companies, institutions, entities and society in general; to boost their commitment to sustainability through an integrative, informed, diverse and professional approach. https://wasaction.com

About Schneider Electric

Schneider's purpose is to create Impact by empowering all to make the most of our energy and resources, bridging progress and sustainability for all. At Schneider, we call this Life Is On.

Our mission is to be the trusted partner in Sustainability and Efficiency.

We are a global industrial technology leader bringing world-leading expertise in electrification, automation and digitization to smart industries, resilient infrastructure, future-proof data centers, intelligent buildings, and intuitive homes. Anchored by our deep domain expertise, we provide integrated end-to-end lifecycle AI enabled Industrial IoT solutions with connected products, automation, software and services, delivering digital twins to enable profitable growth for our customers.

We are a people company with an ecosystem of 150,000 colleagues and more than a million partners operating in over 100 countries to ensure proximity to our customers and stakeholders. We embrace diversity and inclusion in everything we do, guided by our meaningful purpose of a sustainable future for all.

title: Schneider Electric and Women Action Sustainability (WAS) Launch New Report on Climate Adaptation to Build Resilience
bodyText:
* Nearly 40% of companies surveyed for this study have developed climate adaptation plans, yet only 6% have fully implemented adaptation measures.

* This report includes recommendations for large enterprises, the financial sector, and public administration to effectively plan and implement climate adaptation actions to ensure the resilience of businesses and communities amid the climate crisis.



Schneider Electric, the leader in the digital transformation of energy management and automation, has collaborated with Women Action Sustainability (WAS), a non-profit association that promotes sustainability among companies, institutions and society, to publish a new report entitled, "Creating Sustainable Impact: Building Resilience Through Climate Adaptation". This report highlights the interdependencies between public and private stakeholders and the collective responsibility required to drive actions to build resilience amidst escalating climate change impacts.

"At Schneider Electric, we recognize the vital importance of integrating climate risk and adaptation strategies to enhance the resilience of businesses," said Steve Wilhite, President, Schneider Electric Sustainability Business. "Climate change is impacting many companies financially, not only with destruction of physical assets but also due to higher interest and insurance rates. Schneider Electric is dedicated to pushing the boundaries of climate progress, collaborating with our network to integrate sustainable practices throughout our ecosystem."

This report highlights how businesses from various industries and regions are addressing climate-related risks with adaptation strategies and identifies market opportunities and gaps that require attention. The following are several key findings from this report:

* 38% of companies have developed clear climate adaptation plans, however, only 6% have fully implemented outlined adaptation measures.

* Only 12% have detailed methods to quantify the financial impact of physical climate risks.

* Many have experienced climate-related impacts on their supply chains (30%) and on direct operations (28%).

* 30% of companies surveyed do not have insurance coverage to mitigate financial risks linked to climate hazards.

Climate risk is broadly recognized as a financial risk and is expected to have a significant impact on corporate profit and loss statements. The United Nations reports that extreme weather events have led to $ 4 trillion in losses over the past 50 years. With the global temperature escalating, the frequency and severity of climate-related disasters are projected to rise annually, reinforcing the urgency to develop climate adaptation plans and actions. In the UNEP's Adaptation Gap Report 2024, the finance adaptation gap is estimated to be between $ 194-366 billion USD per year, which is a factor for the lag in adaptation planning and implementation efforts.

"Adaptation is highlighted as a major emerging trend, given the increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, and corporations are experiencing the impacts of climate change," said Mónica Chao, President, Women Action Sustainability. "We aim to inspire action in climate adaptation at the corporate level. We invite not only corporations, but all stakeholders, including policymakers, financial institutions, and insurers, to engage in collaboration to drive and enable action."

The report highlights that, while businesses around the world are showing efforts to mitigate their impact on the environment, current ways of operating will need to change to ensure the resilience of activities. This transformation requires investment. The involvement of the banking and financial services sector is key to support companies in the process of implementing their adaptation plans. WAS wants to call on public administration and scientists, also at the global level, to help companies on this path by providing guidance, tools and resources as needed.

Ana Peña, President of Women Action Sustainability's Climate Change Group, adds, "in a world where demands and conditions change rapidly, accelerating infrastructure adaptation strategies is crucial to ensure resilience and efficiency. The ability to anticipate and respond agilely to new challenges and opportunities ensures that infrastructures not only support the present but are also prepared for the future."

This report offers strategic recommendations to help corporations mobilize action, while emphasizing the critical roles of the financial sector, which serves as a catalyst for change, and public administration in facilitating climate adaptation planning. This report also addresses the need for businesses to not only adapt current physical assets, but also proactively design future physical assets to be more resilient and capable of withstanding the impacts of climate change.

Download the full report here.

Women Action Sustainability is a non-profit association, made up of more than 200 women managers, whose goal is to ensure that sustainability is present at the tables where decisions are made at the highest level. Thus, through female leadership, WAS calls on companies, institutions, entities and society in general; to boost their commitment to sustainability through an integrative, informed, diverse and professional approach. https://wasaction.com

About Schneider Electric

Schneider's purpose is to create Impact by empowering all to make the most of our energy and resources, bridging progress and sustainability for all. At Schneider, we call this Life Is On.

Our mission is to be the trusted partner in Sustainability and Efficiency.

We are a global industrial technology leader bringing world-leading expertise in electrification, automation and digitization to smart industries, resilient infrastructure, future-proof data centers, intelligent buildings, and intuitive homes. Anchored by our deep domain expertise, we provide integrated end-to-end lifecycle AI enabled Industrial IoT solutions with connected products, automation, software and services, delivering digital twins to enable profitable growth for our customers.

We are a people company with an ecosystem of 150,000 colleagues and more than a million partners operating in over 100 countries to ensure proximity to our customers and stakeholders. We embrace diversity and inclusion in everything we do, guided by our meaningful purpose of a sustainable future for all.

title: ADB, United Nations Partner to Develop Climate Insurance for Fiji Businesses
bodyText:
SUVA, FIJI -- The Asian Development Bank (ADB), the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF), and the UN Development Programme (UNDP) will help create an insurance market for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Fiji that are increasingly threatened by extreme weather.



Supported by $ 950,000 in technical assistance from the Asia-Pacific Climate Finance Fund (ACliFF), the initiative will research the insurance landscape for small businesses in Fiji, and work with local insurance providers to develop and test pilot products. The initiative builds on the work of the Pacific Insurance and Climate Adaptation Programme (PICAP), which provides parametric insurance to vulnerable communities in the Pacific.

"With small businesses making up such a significant proportion of the Fijian economy and workforce, it is essential to protect this sector," said ADB's Pacific Subregional Office Regional Director Aaron Batten. "This initiative will help lay the foundation for a domestic insurance market specifically designed to meet the needs of these businesses and support climate resilience across critical sectors of the Fijian economy."

Parametric insurance is a form of index-based insurance that pays out when pre-agreed trigger conditions are met, such as rainfall thresholds or wind speeds. With simple rules and pre-approval--there's no need to prove actual losses--parametric insurance can help insulate vulnerable communities from climate hazards by providing fast, pre-defined payouts.

MSMEs account for more than 80% of Fijian businesses and employ more than a quarter of the workforce, according to the Fiji Bureau of Statistics. But the sector remains highly vulnerable to extreme weather, with limited access to tailored insurance solutions that can support recovery and build resilience.

ADB's Country Partnership Strategy for Fiji for 2024-2028 supports the country's resilience to economic and climate-related shocks, and is aligned with the objectives of PICAP to build the financial preparedness of low-income households against natural hazards. PICAP is jointly implemented by UNCDF, UNDP, and the UN University's Institute for Environment and Human Security.

"This innovative approach empowers MSMEs in the world's toughest economies to flourish, strengthen resilience, and foster sustainable development that uplifts communities and leaves no one behind," said UNCDF Executive Secretary Pradeep Kurukulasuriya.

"UNDP is proud to partner in strengthening the resilience of MSMEs," said UNDP Resident Representative for the Pacific Office in Fiji Munkhtuya Altangerel. "This initiative supports our broader efforts across the Pacific to promote risk-informed development, harness digital innovation, and accelerate progress."

ACliFF is a multi-donor trust fund established in April 2017. It seeks to support the development and implementation of financial risk management products that can help unlock capital for climate investments and improve resilience to climate impacts.

ADB is a leading multilateral development bank supporting inclusive, resilient, and sustainable growth across Asia and the Pacific. Working with its members and partners to solve complex challenges together, ADB harnesses innovative financial tools and strategic partnerships to transform lives, build quality infrastructure, and safeguard our planet. Founded in 1966, ADB is owned by 69 members--50 from the region.

title: Neighbourhoods at risk of 'dangerous heatwaves'
bodyText:
THE areas in Greater Manchester that are most at risk from 'dangerous' heatwaves have been revealed by an environmental charity.

Friends of the Earth have identified 4,715 'high heat' neighbourhoods across England based on heatwave data from 2022 when temperatures topped 40C. More than 4,500 deaths that year were linked to heat - the highest number over the last 35 years.

It comes as the UK is set for a fourth heatwave this summer with temperatures expected to reach 34C in parts of the country.

Health authorities have issued a yellow heat health alert covering six English regions. The North West of England is not affected.

In Greater Manchester, temperatures were expected to reach highs of 31C today, according to the Met Office. New analysis by Friends of the Earth has found that there are nearly 500 'high heat' neighbourhoods across the North West.

This includes most of the neighbourhoods within the M60 ring road as well as parts of Wigan, Oldham, Tameside and Stockport.

Researchers from the charity also identified nearly 2,000 neighbourhoods that face 'enhanced risks' of health impacts from heat.

These risks are linked to physical characteristics of an area, such as little green space and lots of flats, more physical risk, such as having an older population and health issues, and a 'low ability' to respond to rising temperatures, for example due to low income. In total, 253 'high heat' neighbourhoods in the North West of England were found to have 'enhanced risks' of health impacts from heat.

This includes the city of Manchester and central parts of Salford as well as the towns of Bolton, Bury, Oldham and Ashtonunder-Lyne. The researchers also revealed that within the nearly 500 'high heat' neighbourhoods across the North West, there are 937 care homes and nursing homes - including 69 in Manchester, 65 in Stockport and 31 in Tameside - as well as 107 hospitals and 954 nurseries. Friends of the Earth campaigner Denis Fernando said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all - but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients.

"The government must act now and urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms - as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

title: -Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli Appointed African Development Fund Champion
bodyText:
Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli Appointed African Development Fund Champion.

The African Development Fund has appointed Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli, President and CEO of the ONE Campaign, as a Champion for its 17th replenishment cycle, ADF-17. This cycle comes at a pivotal moment as the Fund seeks to scale catalytic investments to advance resilience, integration, and inclusive growth across Africa's most vulnerable economies.



As Champion, Nwuneli will play a role in mobilizing support for ADF-17. She will draw on her extensive leadership experience to amplify the Fund's visibility, foster strategic partnerships, and engage a broad spectrum of stakeholders around its core priorities-climate adaptation, regional integration, and targeted support for countries facing fragility and conflict.

'This partnership with the ONE Campaign comes at a critical moment for the African Development Fund. As Champion for ADF-17, Ndidi brings a powerful voice and trusted leadership that will help elevate the Fund's visibility, highlight Africa's development priorities, and reinforce the importance of long-term, impactful investment across the continent,' said Valerie Dabady, African Development Bank Manager for Resource Mobilization and Partnerships.

An internationally recognized expert in social innovation and development, Nwuneli has spent more than 25 years advancing equity, food systems transformation, and youth empowerment across Africa. She is the founder of LEAP Africa and African Food Changemakers, co-founder of Sahel Consulting and AACE Foods, and serves on the boards of the Rockefeller Foundation, Stanbic IBTC Group, and the Bridgespan Group. She is also a member of the World Economic Forum's Advisory Council for Young Global Leaders, Fondation CHANEL and IFC's Women LEAD Africa Alliance.

'Africa stands at a pivotal moment, poised for growth and ready to drive greater contributions to the global economy. Seizing this opportunity requires immediate and sustained investment. The African Development Fund plays a vital role in channeling the resources needed now to unlock long-term prosperity across the continent. I am honored to serve as Champion for ADF-17 and to help mobilize the bold, strategic support required to fuel inclusive growth and strengthen communities across Africa,' said Nwuneli.

The ONE Campaign is a nonpartisan organization fighting for a more just world by demanding the investments needed to create economic opportunities and healthier lives in Africa. Through trusted and dynamic advocacy, grassroots activism, and strategic partnerships, ONE influences decision-makers to act on the world's most pressing challenges.

Established in 1972, the African Development Fund is the concessional window of the African Development Bank Group and a critical source of finance for 37 low-income African countries. To date, the Fund has committed over $ 58 billion to operations that improve infrastructure, strengthen agricultural networks, support governance reforms, and foster regional trade. Its impact is further multiplied through blended finance, policy dialogue, and specialized instruments such as the Transition Support Facility and the Climate Action Window.

The pledging session for ADF-17 will take place in December 2025. A strong replenishment will expand the Fund's ability to deliver transformative, African-led solutions to the continent's most pressing development challenges.

title: -Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli Appointed African Development Fund Champion
bodyText:
August 19, 2025

Release date- 18082025 - Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli Appointed African Development Fund Champion.

The African Development Fund has appointed Ndidi Okonkwo Nwuneli, President and CEO of the ONE Campaign, as a Champion for its 17th replenishment cycle, ADF-17. This cycle comes at a pivotal moment as the Fund seeks to scale catalytic investments to advance resilience, integration, and inclusive growth across Africa's most vulnerable economies.



As Champion, Nwuneli will play a role in mobilizing support for ADF-17. She will draw on her extensive leadership experience to amplify the Fund's visibility, foster strategic partnerships, and engage a broad spectrum of stakeholders around its core priorities-climate adaptation, regional integration, and targeted support for countries facing fragility and conflict.

'This partnership with the ONE Campaign comes at a critical moment for the African Development Fund. As Champion for ADF-17, Ndidi brings a powerful voice and trusted leadership that will help elevate the Fund's visibility, highlight Africa's development priorities, and reinforce the importance of long-term, impactful investment across the continent,' said Valerie Dabady, African Development Bank Manager for Resource Mobilization and Partnerships.

An internationally recognized expert in social innovation and development, Nwuneli has spent more than 25 years advancing equity, food systems transformation, and youth empowerment across Africa. She is the founder of LEAP Africa and African Food Changemakers, co-founder of Sahel Consulting and AACE Foods, and serves on the boards of the Rockefeller Foundation, Stanbic IBTC Group, and the Bridgespan Group. She is also a member of the World Economic Forum's Advisory Council for Young Global Leaders, Fondation CHANEL and IFC's Women LEAD Africa Alliance.

'Africa stands at a pivotal moment, poised for growth and ready to drive greater contributions to the global economy. Seizing this opportunity requires immediate and sustained investment. The African Development Fund plays a vital role in channeling the resources needed now to unlock long-term prosperity across the continent. I am honored to serve as Champion for ADF-17 and to help mobilize the bold, strategic support required to fuel inclusive growth and strengthen communities across Africa,' said Nwuneli.

The ONE Campaign is a nonpartisan organization fighting for a more just world by demanding the investments needed to create economic opportunities and healthier lives in Africa. Through trusted and dynamic advocacy, grassroots activism, and strategic partnerships, ONE influences decision-makers to act on the world's most pressing challenges.

Established in 1972, the African Development Fund is the concessional window of the African Development Bank Group and a critical source of finance for 37 low-income African countries. To date, the Fund has committed over $ 58 billion to operations that improve infrastructure, strengthen agricultural networks, support governance reforms, and foster regional trade. Its impact is further multiplied through blended finance, policy dialogue, and specialized instruments such as the Transition Support Facility and the Climate Action Window.

The pledging session for ADF-17 will take place in December 2025. A strong replenishment will expand the Fund's ability to deliver transformative, African-led solutions to the continent's most pressing development challenges.

Learn more about the African Development Fund and ADF-17 at: https://adf.afdb.org

Learn more about the ONE Campaign: https://www.one.org

title: Government of Togo Raises USD226.13 Million in Private Placement of Sustainable Loan
bodyText:
Government of Togo, a West African nation on the Gulf of Guinea, has raised EUR200 million (USD226.13 million) in private placement of sustainable loan. The loan is funded by African Development Fund, Legal & General (L&G) and Deutsche Bank. The funds mobilized under the partial credit guarantee will be allocated to green and social projects including climate adaptation, biodiversity preservation, sustainable agriculture, access to clean energy and pollution control. This is in line with Togo's Sustainable Financing Framework as well as the country's 2020-2025 Government Roadmap, which prioritizes inclusive growth and climate-resilient development. The African Development Bank acted as lead arranger in the transaction.

title: -ADB, United Nations Partner to Develop Climate Insurance for Fiji Businesses
bodyText:
The Asian Development Bank (ADB), the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF), and the UN Development Programme (UNDP) will help create an insurance market for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Fiji that are increasingly threatened by extreme weather.



Supported by $ 950,000 in technical assistance from the Asia-Pacific Climate Finance Fund (ACliFF), the initiative will research the insurance landscape for small businesses in Fiji, and work with local insurance providers to develop and test pilot products. The initiative builds on the work of the Pacific Insurance and Climate Adaptation Programme (PICAP), which provides parametric insurance to vulnerable communities in the Pacific.

'With small businesses making up such a significant proportion of the Fijian economy and workforce, it is essential to protect this sector,' said ADB's Pacific Subregional Office Regional Director Aaron Batten. 'This initiative will help lay the foundation for a domestic insurance market specifically designed to meet the needs of these businesses and support climate resilience across critical sectors of the Fijian economy.'

Parametric insurance is a form of index-based insurance that pays out when pre-agreed trigger conditions are met, such as rainfall thresholds or wind speeds. With simple rules and pre-approval-there's no need to prove actual losses-parametric insurance can help insulate vulnerable communities from climate hazards by providing fast, pre-defined payouts.

MSMEs account for more than 80% of Fijian businesses and employ more than a quarter of the workforce, according to the Fiji Bureau of Statistics. But the sector remains highly vulnerable to extreme weather, with limited access to tailored insurance solutions that can support recovery and build resilience.

ADB's Country Partnership Strategy for Fiji for 2024-2028 supports the country's resilience to economic and climate-related shocks, and is aligned with the objectives of PICAP to build the financial preparedness of low-income households against natural hazards. PICAP is jointly implemented by UNCDF, UNDP, and the UN University's Institute for Environment and Human Security.

'This innovative approach empowers MSMEs in the world's toughest economies to flourish, strengthen resilience, and foster sustainable development that uplifts communities and leaves no one behind,' said UNCDF Executive Secretary Pradeep Kurukulasuriya.

'UNDP is proud to partner in strengthening the resilience of MSMEs,' said UNDP Resident Representative for the Pacific Office in Fiji Munkhtuya Altangerel. 'This initiative supports our broader efforts across the Pacific to promote risk-informed development, harness digital innovation, and accelerate progress.'

ACliFF is a multi-donor trust fund established in April 2017. It seeks to support the development and implementation of financial risk management products that can help unlock capital for climate investments and improve resilience to climate impacts.

ADB is a leading multilateral development bank supporting inclusive, resilient, and sustainable growth across Asia and the Pacific. Working with its members and partners to solve complex challenges together, ADB harnesses innovative financial tools and strategic partnerships to transform lives, build quality infrastructure, and safeguard our planet. Founded in 1966, ADB is owned by 69 members-50 from the region.

title: Castle's gardens recognised for 'historic charm and thoughtful design'
bodyText:
A County Durham castle-s gardens have been recognised on the international stage for their 'historic charm and thoughtful design'.

Raby Castle-s recently redesigned 18th-century walled gardens and wider landscape scheme earned second place in the Management or Development of a Historic Park or Garden category at the 2025 European Garden Awards.

The County Durham estate shares the runner-up position with South Cliff Gardens in the UK, while the top spot went to Promenades de Reims in France.Alistair Baldwin, Lady Barnard and Lord Barnard (Image: Supplied)

Lady Barnard, creative director and custodian of Raby Castle and Estates, said: "We're immensely proud to have achieved international recognition for the beautiful gardens and spaces throughout Raby Castle-s grounds and I-d like to extend my thanks and congratulations to both Luciano and Alistair.

"The spaces they have created are elegant, tranquil and perfectly encapsulate the fascinating heritage of Raby."

The award celebrates the work of garden designer Luciano Giubbilei and landscape architect Alistair Baldwin, who collaborated with Lady Barnard to transform Raby Castle-s grounds as part of a three-year regeneration plan completed in 2024.The Round House at Raby Castle, Park and Gardens (Image: Jason Ingram)

Mr Baldwin led the redesign of the castle-s public areas, while Mr Giubbilei worked with Lady Barnard on the walled gardens.

Since 2010, the European Garden Awards have honoured around 140 sites across 23 countries for excellence in historic garden conservation, contemporary design, and climate adaptation.

Raby Castle-s gardens are also in the running for the Historic Houses 2025 Garden of the Year Award, sponsored by Christie-s.Raby Castle's Walled Gardens (Image: Jason Ingram)

Dickon Harding, gardens and landscape manager at Raby Castle, said: "The gardens team have worked exceptionally hard to maintain the impressive vision of both Luciano and Lady Barnard, ensuring the five-acre space continues to flourish as they had hoped and envisaged.

"It-s been wonderful to see how the three different areas within the walled gardens have matured over the different seasons, and we feel an immense sense of pride that we get to work in such a peaceful and beautiful place, steeped in history.

"Winning the Garden of the Year Award would be a brilliant achievement and thank you to everyone who has already voted for Raby in this category."

Raby is one of eight finalists selected from hundreds of sites across the UK, all of which offer free entry to Historic Houses members.

Members of the public can support Raby Castle, Park and Gardens by voting in the Historic Houses 2025 Garden of the Year Award at www.historichouses.org/vote-goya.

title: Highlights: Austrian Talk Shows German 2-7 Aug 25
bodyText:
Main themes on selected current affairs programmes on Austrian TV on 2-7 August 2025

Austria's media used the political summer recess to revisit major issues through interviews with political representatives and expert conversations.

Greens reject 'woke prohibition party' image

New Greens leader Leonore Gewessler opened this year's summer talk series on commercial broadcaster KroneTV (2 August, 09:20 GMT). In conversation with news editor in chief Katia Wagner, she addressed welcome policies, gender asterisks and wokeness accusations.

Gewessler sought to dispel prejudices about the Greens as a "woke" prohibition party: "We're not the ones looking for perfect people. We're not perfect ourselves." She noted owning an electric car and meeting her husband on an airplane.

Asked how she would convince an FPOe voter who eats meat and drives an SUV, Gewessler replied: "I'm not here to tell you what to eat or how to get around." She wanted to listen more - something that "quite simply came far too short" during her ministerial term.

On migration, she stated: "I'm for humanity and order. We have to provide support. But it's clear we can't shoulder everything alone." She described the FPOe's migration policy as "maximally xenophobic, racist and disrespectful".

Government scapegoating

Gewessler criticised the current federal government for blaming subsidies from her term for budgetary strain while cutting climate programmes. "The current government is trying to find a scapegoat for its austerity policy." She argued savings could be made in road construction rather than cutting the climate ticket or climate bonus.

On women's policy, after internal Green debates on trans rights, she declared: "Trans women are women." She defended EU MEP Lena Schilling despite past criticism: "I'm very pleased we were able to bring her into the Greens."

Asked whether an FPOe voter could be a good person, Gewessler answered diplomatically: "I'd try to have a discussion with him. We might not see eye to eye, but we could still have a beer together."

Energy grid challenges

E-Control chairman Wolfgang Urbantschitsch addressed electricity grid charges on public broadcaster ORF's current affairs flagship ZiB 2 (3 August, 20:00 GMT), assuring viewers his regulator would "ensure affordable energy supply".

He explained that 5bn euros had been invested in grid expansion over 10 years, "all paid for by grid customers". Annual grid costs of 3.5bn euros were currently split: 90% consumers, 10% providers. New grid charges would serve as control measures: on sunny weekends when "electricity is in abundance", charges should deter photovoltaic producers from feeding in additional electricity.

The draft provides support for 250,000 low-income households, saving them "300 euros per year or more". Urbantschitsch noted Austria has 130 electricity grid operators and "common planning would be good", potentially curbing costs and investments.

Gas security

Regarding the EU's $250bn energy purchase commitment to the USA, Urbantschitsch expressed doubt: "At the moment, I find it very difficult to imagine the implementation." He warned against replacing "one dependency with another".

On gas supply concerns, despite July storage levels at 73% versus previous years' 90%, Urbantschitsch assured: "No, there is no need to worry." Austria had "succeeded in moving away entirely from Russian gas", putting 80% of Russian supply "behind it" with diversified sources.

Flood protection and climate adaptation

Agriculture Minister Norbert Totschnig (OeVP) called flood protection a "central policy measure" on commercial broadcaster PULS 24's current affairs programme Beide Seiten Live (3 August, 19:00 GMT), announcing the repair bonus resumption date.

Following September 2024's devastating floods, which killed five people and forced evacuations, renaturation became a key debate focus. Totschnig emphasised climate adaptation was "absolutely necessary": "We know from all studies, and also from observing nature, that we will increasingly be confronted with extreme weather events."

He cited Austria's proactive approach, highlighting the Triestingtal retention basin in Lower Austria, which "proved its full worth during the floods in September". However, he distinguished between technical protective measures and ecological renaturation.

Totschnig announced "200m euros will be available for the renaturation of rivers until 2027," citing examples like the River Ybbs-Danube confluence. The repair bonus would resume in November with 30m euros annually until 2029.

Israeli military resistance to Netanyahu

Israeli historian Tom Segev described senior military figures opposing Prime Minister Netanyahu as a "dramatic moment" on public broadcaster ORF's current affairs flagship ZiB 2 (5 August, 20:00 GMT) with presenter Armin Wolf.

With 60,000 dead, two-thirds of Gaza buildings destroyed, and Hamas holding around 50 hostages, senior Israeli army representatives issued statements opposing Netanyahu's war expansion plans.

Segev, speaking via video link from Jerusalem, called it "a rather dramatic moment in the history of this war. I believe that tonight the majority of Israelis are not standing with Netanyahu, but with the army's Chief of General Staff."

He suggested Netanyahu wants to prolong the war "to avoid early elections and to escape corruption proceedings: He will do everything to stay in office."

Segev assessed Israel's victory chances as virtually non-existent: Hamas's army had become a guerrilla force, and "it is very, very rare for a government to defeat a guerrilla organisation."

Expressing personal distress, Segev said: "I am ashamed of what we have done to Gaza. I feel complicit. This has all happened in my name, and unfortunately, unfortunately, I cannot change it." He could not imagine a two-state solution, seeing the only possibility as both sides developing interest in "peaceful neighbourliness".

Migration policy and 'Trump scenario' warning

Asylum expert Gerald Knaus made urgent pleas for better migration agreements on public broadcaster ORF's ZiB 2 (7 August, 20:00 GMT) with presenter Stefan Lenglinger, warning the public must be convinced "that control is possible without sacrificing our values."

Reflecting on 10 years since the 2015 refugee crisis and Angela Merkel's "We can do this" statement, Knaus acknowledged positive outcomes - many found protection in willing European countries including Austria. However, he noted EU discussions had "gone round in circles for a decade, lacking thought and impact".

When centrist parties promise control but fail to deliver, Knaus warned it unsettles the public: "That is politically dangerous, because without majority public support, a humane refugee policy is of course not possible in the long term."

External border solutions

Knaus blamed "too many sham debates" for failed plans. The solution lay not at Austria's external border but required agreements with other states: "Unless you do it like Donald Trump and rely on terror." He called for realistic debates on returns, emphasising countries must be willing to take people back.

Regarding proposals to reinterpret the European Convention on Human Rights, Knaus replied: "These are governments that are failing." He warned against governments using courts as excuses: "When governments use the courts as an excuse, that's when it becomes dangerous."

Looking ahead, Knaus warned of the "Donald Trump scenario" if humane control could not be proven in the next three years, describing the US approach as "reducing irregular migration by suspending the rule of law, using terror against people [...] having them hunted by a special unit of Homeland Security."

"That is dangerous, because that's when democracy perishes," he concluded, calling for "better agreements, secure third-country agreements that actually work".

title: -Europa-Commission positively assesses Belgium's third payment request of EUR614 million under NextGenerationEU
bodyText:
Today, the Commission positively assessed Belgium's third payment request for EUR614 million under the Recovery and Resilience Facility, the cornerstone of NextGenerationEU.

This assessment marks an important step towards the disbursement of EUR594 million in grants and EUR20 million in loans to support Belgium's economic growth and reforms.



The Commission found that Belgium has satisfactorily achieved 21 milestones and 14 targets that are anticipated to benefit Belgian citizens and businesses. Reforms and investments focus on spending reviews, labour market, childcare infrastructure, education, training and climate adaptation. They also include the development of railways, urban mobility solutions, cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, digitalisation, hydrogen transport, and research and development.

Energy transition is another strong element of the Belgian recovery plan. It includes the development of renewable energies, the expansion of electric vehicle charging infrastructure and the renovation of private and social housing, to address the challenges of poor insulation in many buildings. This will enhance living comfort, lower energy bills and consumption, reduce carbon footprints, mitigate energy poverty, and foster social inclusion.

Next steps

The Commission has now sent this preliminary assessment of Belgium's fulfilment of the milestones and targets required for this payment to the Economic and Financial Committee (EFC), which has four weeks to deliver its opinion. The payment to Belgium can take place following the EFC's opinion, and the adoption of a payment decision by the Commission.

Background

Belgium's recovery and resilience plan includes a wide range of investment and reform measures. The plan will be financed by EUR5 billion in grants and EUR244 million in loans.

An interactive map of projects financed by the RRF, including the Recovery and Resilience Scoreboard, is available online. More information on the process of payment requests under the RRF can be found equally online.

title: Growing resilience: Why urban green spaces must evolve for a hotter future
bodyText:
Pictured: An artist's impression of Grosvenor Square Gardens
As we move into the height of summer, and with the hottest day of the year already reached, the impacts of climate change are becoming unmistakable. July 2024 saw the world break the record for the .


Heatwaves are no longer rare events; they're becoming the norm. Cities, with their often dense infrastructure and limited green cover, are particularly vulnerable to extreme temperatures, flooding, and pollution. To adapt and thrive in this changing climate, urban resilience must evolve, and that evolution must be green.
Traditionally, city adaptation strategies have focused on 'grey' infrastructure like stormwater drains and reinforced buildings. But as these systems reach their limits, with London alone said to have '' according to the Mayor,  the case for nature-based solutions has never been stronger.
Green spaces, when designed with purpose, can offer extraordinary value. They can cool urban areas, absorb excess rainwater, trap air pollutants, support biodiversity, and enhance human well-being.
Beyond aesthetics
The key lies in how these spaces are created. Too many of our parks and gardens were designed with beauty and recreation as their sole purpose. Manicured lawns and ornamental flowerbeds might look pleasing and certainly have their place, but they often underperform when it comes to ecological function. As a result, we're missing crucial opportunities to make these green spaces work harder for us, and for our cities to be more climate-resilient, better support nature and more beautiful.
We need a shift in mindset. Urban green spaces shouldn't be ornamental; they should be designed to multitask with climate resilience and civic enjoyment combined. Imagine tree-lined corridors that lower street temperatures, wetlands that manage flood risk, wildflower meadows buzzing with pollinators and plants that actively capture carbon. These are not futuristic concepts; they are practical, proven interventions that can transform how cities cope with a warming world.
This is the approach we are taking at Grosvenor Square.
As London's second-largest garden square, Grosvenor Square has long been a green oasis. But like many historic spaces, it was not designed with climate adaptation in mind. That's why we're undertaking a radical transformation to reimagine the square to prioritise resilience, biodiversity, community, and beauty in equal measure.
When the project is complete in Summer 2026, the square will feature around 70,000 new plants, 44 new trees, wetlands, and approximately 80,000 bulbs. We're increasing the planted area from just 140 square metres to nearly 8,000 square metres. This isn't just more greenery; it's a complete rethinking of how an urban space can serve both people and planet.
The new Grosvenor Square will be a haven for wildlife, with carefully selected species to support pollinators, birds, and other native fauna. It will offer shaded, cooler spaces for people to rest and connect. And it will manage rainfall more effectively, helping to reduce the strain on the city's drainage systems during extreme weather.
Wellbeing in the cities of the future
Importantly, this transformation is not just about climate adaptation; it's about enhancing the quality of urban life. Well-designed green spaces have been shown to reduce stress, improve mental health, and foster stronger communities. They make cities not only more resilient, but also more inclusive and inspiring.
As we plan the cities of the future, we must stop treating nature as an afterthought or a luxury. It is essential infrastructure in the same vein as roads, buildings, and transport systems. When green infrastructure is designed to be functional and beautiful, it becomes something even more powerful: a source of pride, connection, and resilience.
At Grosvenor Square, we're proud to be demonstrating what's possible when we design with both nature and people in mind. Our hope is that this project inspires other cities to follow suit because adapting to climate change isn't just about surviving, it's about growing stronger.
Ed Green is sustainability director at Grosvenor Property UK

title: Cryogenx Raises USD2.2 Million in Seed Funding
bodyText:
London-based Cryogenx has raised (EURO)1.9 million (USD2.2 million) as part of Seed funding round to accelerate the development of its portable cooling technology to combat heat strokes. The UK Innovation & Science Seed Fund (UKI2S), managed by Future Planet Capital, has invested (EURO)495k in Cryogenx as part of the funding round. Founder and CEO of Cryogenx, Matt Anderson, added: "Heatstroke isn't just an isolated risk; it's a rising global threat - and existing solutions simply aren't practical enough to meet the challenge.

We've designed CGX1 as a defibrillator for heatstroke, providing frontline responders and military personnel the ability to treat heat-related illness effectively, wherever it strikes. "The backing from UKI2S is pivotal - it not only validates our mission but gives us the resources to accelerate regulatory clearance, scale manufacturing, and get this lifesaving technology into the hands of those who need it most." Founded in 2020, Cryogenx develops portable on-demand cooling devices designed to rapidly treat heatstroke and heat-related illnesses in-the-field. Their flagship product, CGX1, eliminates the need for cold-chain logistics and can be deployed in remote, industrial, military, and emergency response settings. The company is targeting global markets across defence, industry, and climate adaptation sectors.

title: The future of youth employability in a green economy
bodyText:
Capgemini co-developed a with UNICEF, as part of our partnership supporting its Green Rising initiative, to explore these questions. The data revealed that despite rising climate anxiety, the majority of young people in the UK (75%) and the rest of the world (72%) remain hopeful that there is still time to address climate change. However, the findings also make it clear that ensuring young people are both equipped for and able to access sustainability-adjacent jobs is key to tackling this enormous challenge.


The economic opportunity
According to recent , the net-zero sector is growing three times faster than the overall UK economy. Yet estimates suggest that there is a shortage of around skilled workers, which is half of the number of green jobs (defined as 'jobs that help the environment') required to help drive the green economy.
Our data shows that in the UK, 66% of young people believe they already have the green skills necessary to succeed in today's workforce, a figure that is notably higher than the global average of 44%. At the same time, only 45% feel that these skills will present new career opportunities, which is the lowest proportion among all high-income countries in our research.
While nearly two-thirds of UK youth are interested in working in green jobs, there remains uncertainty about whether their skills will be recognised and rewarded by employers. This demonstrates that despite increasing confidence among youth that they possess green skills, the route from green skills to meaningful employment is not yet clear or accessible enough. Addressing this challenge will be key to closing the green skills gap.
A shared challenge across the global North and South
While the physical impacts of climate change, such as extreme weather events and resource scarcity, are often more severe in the Global South, our research shows that climate anxiety is widespread. Over two-thirds of 16-24 year olds globally say they are worried about how climate change could affect their future. In response to these anxieties, young people in both the Global North and Global South are eager to contribute, advocate, and act on climate issues. 71% percent of global youth and 62% in the UK believe they should influence environmental policy. However, less than half feel their perspectives are genuinely considered by government decision-makers. This gap between motivation and influence highlights the need for greater collaboration between youth, employers, and policymakers to ensure youth voices are heard and amplified in the climate transition.
Grassroots social action: a pilot that shows promise for inclusive climate action
Encouraging grassroots social action can play a key role in giving young people a stronger voice on climate change and ensuring that no-one is left behind as new technologies and industries emerge. In the UK, young people from disadvantaged backgrounds are already to be not in education, employment or training than their better-off peers, where they would gain crucial employment experience. With green skills becoming increasingly important in the modern workplace, this could further exacerbate social inequalities and digital exclusion.
Recognising that the transition to a green economy must be inclusive, we worked with the (DOT) UK on the Climate Champion Initiative, a pilot programme in the North East of England aimed at young people facing social and economic barriers.
Through co-design workshops and hands-on learning, ten young people with experience of marginalisation helped shape the programme and its curriculum. Over three structured sessions, participants focused on co-designing the programme itself, exploring local climate challenges and building digital and employability skills. The impact was clear: 77% of participants reported greater awareness of digital tools for community engagement and 100% reported improved confidence in co-design and collaboration. This pilot phase has laid a strong foundation for the next stage, where more young people will be engaged in creating practical, community-driven climate solutions.
Empowering young people to help tackle climate change
This initiative offers important insights into how to empower young people to be active participants in tackling climate change. Genuine engagement begins by meeting young people where they are and recognising the value of their experience. Integrating digital and green skills not only improves employability but also gives young people the tools and confidence to drive meaningful change in their own communities. The combination of co-design and hands-on learning helps to build confidence and ownership, making programmes like this both more impactful and easier to scale.
This approach underscores the value of inclusive, place-based models for equipping the next generation with the skills and agency to shape the green transition and foster resilient communities.
Bringing global lessons to the UK context
The DOT programme builds on experience from successful climate and skills initiatives in Africa and the MENA region, where community-based, hands-on learning has been effective in empowering young people as climate leaders. In these regions, youth are often at the forefront of climate adaptation and mitigation efforts, responding directly to immediate and tangible climate risks.
Innovative educational approaches and the capacity for climate adaptation demonstrated in the Global South offer important lessons for the UK. The journey towards an inclusive green economy is not straightforward, and ongoing learning, experimentation, and adjustment are essential to address evolving climate challenges. Cross-regional exchange enables the sharing of effective solutions, challenges assumptions, and ensures climate education remains relevant and responsive in different local contexts.
Looking ahead: digital inclusion as a foundation for employability in the green sector
It is also important to address the clear link between digital inclusion and green skills, both of which are central to employability in the green economy. Many of the UK's most vulnerable young people risk exclusion from new opportunities without access to digital skills and tools. The integration of digital and green education, as seen in the DOT pilot, is not just about preparing for green jobs, but about ensuring all young people can participate in and shape the green transition.
Bridging the gap between youth ambition and employment in the green economy requires more than just equipping young people with skills; it begins with building a strong base of green knowledge. As the UK explores innovative pathways for climate action and prepares young people for the future, learning from both local pilots and global best practice will help ensure no one is left behind, and that youth optimism, energy, and ideas are truly harnessed for a sustainable future.
Sally Caughey is UK Head of Digital Inclusion for Capgemini

title: Homeowners warned of flood risk as lake starts to break through ice dam
bodyText:
A huge basin of rainwater and snowmelt dammed by Alaska’s Mendenhall glacier has started to release, and officials on Tuesday urged residents in some parts of Juneau to evacuate ahead of what could be a record surge of floodwater downstream.

Officials in recent days have been warning people in the flood zone to be ready to evacuate.

On Tuesday morning, they confirmed water had started escaping the ice dam and flowing downstream, with flooding expected from late on Tuesday into Wednesday.

Flooding from the basin has become an annual concern and, in recent years, has swept away houses and swamped hundreds of homes.

Government agencies installed a temporary levy this year in hopes of guarding against widespread damage.

“This will be a new record, based on all of the information that we have,” Nicole Ferrin, a National Weather Service meteorologist, told a news conference on Tuesday.

The Mendenhall glacier, a thinning, retreating glacier that is a major tourist attraction in south-east Alaska, acts as a dam for Suicide Basin, which fills each spring and summer with rainwater and snowmelt.

The basin itself was left behind when a smaller glacier nearby retreated.

When the water in the basin builds up enough pressure, it forces its way under or around the ice dam, entering Mendenhall Lake and eventually the Mendenhall River.

Before the basin reached the limit of its capacity and began overtopping over the weekend, the water level was rising rapidly – as much as 1.22 metres per day during especially sunny or rainy days, according to the National Weather Service.

The threat of so-called glacier outburst flooding has troubled parts of Juneau since 2011. In some years, there has been limited flooding of streets or properties near the lake or river.

But 2023 and 2024 marked successive years of record flooding, with the river last August cresting at 4.9m – 30cm over the prior record set a year earlier, and flooding extending farther into the Mendenhall Valley.

This year’s flooding was predicted to crest at between 4.96m and 5.12m.

Last year, nearly 300 residences were damaged.

A large outburst can release some 15 billion gallons of water, according to the University of Alaska Southeast and Alaska Climate Adaptation Science Centre.

That’s the equivalent of nearly 23,000 Olympic-size swimming pools. During last year’s flood, the flow rate in the rushing Mendenhall River was about half that of Niagara Falls, the researchers said.

City officials responded to concerns from property owners this year by working with state, federal and tribal entities to install a temporary levee along roughly 2.5 miles of riverbank in an attempt to guard against widespread flooding.

The installation of about 10,000 1.2m barriers is intended to protect more than 460 properties from flood levels similar to last year, said Nate Rumsey, deputy director with the city’s engineering and public works department.

The US army corps of engineers is at the start of what is expected to be a years-long process of studying conditions in the region and examining options for a more permanent solution.

The timeline has angered some residents, who say it is unreasonable.

Outburst floods are expected to continue as long as the Mendenhall Glacier acts as an ice dam to seal off the basin, which could span another 25-60 years, according to the university and science centre researchers.

title: Denso acquires Axia Vegetable Seeds to drive agritech expansion
bodyText:
(Alliance News) - Denso Corp on Friday announced the acquisition of Axia Vegetable Seeds BV to advance the company's strategic expansion into the agritech sector.

Denso, a Kariya, Japan-based automotive components manufacturer, did not disclose the financial terms of its acquisition of the Naaldwijk, Netherlands-based vegetable seed breeding company.

As food shortages become more prevalent with climate change, alongside global population growth, the company recognises the increasing need to secure stable agricultural production to meet demand.

Denso said: "Denso and Axia Vegetable Seeds will collaborate to combine industrial technology with seed development to create high-quality seeds suitable for automated farming approaches and climate adaptation. Additionally, by leveraging Denso's image recognition and [artificial intelligence] technologies, the two companies aim to shorten the development period of new seeds and bring higher value-added seeds to market more quickly."

Yasushi Mukai, executive officer, Food Value Chain division, added: "By integrating the technologies and expertise of both the Denso Group and Axia, we will create new value and realize our vision of providing safe and delicious food anytime, anywhere, and for everyone."

Denso shares closed 0.8% higher at JPY1,942.00 each in Tokyo on Friday.

By Elijah Dale, Alliance News senior reporter Asia-Pacific

title: -Utrecht University: Drivers of vulnerability in deltas
bodyText:
July 8, 2025

Release date- 07072025 - Deltares, Utrecht University, Oxford University, Wageningen University, TU Delft, University of Southampton and University of East Anglia have jointly developed a new framework that identifies the key drivers of change in deltas worldwide. From Utrecht University, Dr. Gualbert Oude Essink contributed to this framework. It provides a clear basis for prioritising timely, locally grounded action with a holistic understanding of scale in time and space. The results of their research were published today in Nature Climate Change.



Deeper understanding

Deltas around the world, such as the Rhine, Mekong, Ganges-Brahmaputra-Meghna, and Nile, are threatened by climate change, facing rising sea levels and increasing frequency of extreme events. Today, approximately 500 million people live within or adjacent to delta systems. Effective adaptation in these complex and dynamic environments requires more than isolated measures, that often overlook an important step in deeper assessment of the system as a whole. It calls for a deeper understanding of the systems that shape them.

10 drivers of change in deltas worldwide

To address this, Deltares and an international team of researchers have developed a diagnostic conceptual framework that offers a systems perspective as a first step for climate adaptation in deltas. They have identified 10 drivers of change in deltas worldwide, linked with their direct and indirect impacts across scales in time and space (divided in centuries, decades or temporal scales). These drivers are climate change, sea level rise, deforestation, intense agriculture, urbanisation, impoundments, land subsidence, ground water extraction, flood defences, and resources mining. The framework is designed to help identify and understand the interconnectivities within the biophysical system, from source to sink, and how these link with local/regional/transboundary socio-economic structures. This can also help facilitating a dialogue within various stakeholders towards better system understanding and a building consensus among stakeholders, and co-development of solutions.

'Deltas are the most complex coastal systems in the world and recognising these multiple drivers and how they operate in each delta is fundamental to finding solutions,' says co-author Robert Nicholls (University of East Anglia/University of Southampton).

Anthropogenic drivers have immediate impact

While climate change threatens the world's deltas, anthropogenic drivers (largely reflected in sediment starvation and resource extraction, profound land-use change, and hydrological regime shifts) can outpace climate change in the short to medium term. Nearly all local anthropogenic drivers result in measurable impacts within years or decades, emphasising the significance and relevance of local and regional drivers for effective and timely climate adaptation and policy development.

'If we want to give deltas a real chance at long-term climate resilience, we need collective comprehension of the human footprint and the underlying drivers of change,' says main author Sepehr Eslami (Deltares).

Three years of research

The research was inspired by the work of the Rise and Fall Project, a collaboration between Deltares and the Utrecht University, of which Prof. dr. Piet Hoekstra (UU) was the project lead. Over a period of nearly three years, the team combined decades of knowledge on vulnerabilities in deltas and adaptation efforts to develop a framework that can facilitate diagnosing the key processes and interactions shaping a delta system. The goal: to offer a holistic foundation for planning effective, context-sensitive adaptation strategies.

A tool for policy and practice

This diagnostic framework is intended to support policymakers, technocrats, engineers, and stakeholders in developing locally grounded adaptation strategies that are both realistic and resilient. Initiatives such as the International Panel for Deltas and Coastal Areas (IPDC), Partners voor Water Invest International can apply the framework as a crucial very first step to improve early-stage understanding and adaptation planning.

'By promoting system-level thinking, this framework encourages more critical and collaborative approaches to adaptation. It helps identify the solutions with the highest chance of being implemented successfully, especially when embedded in a longer-term vision,' says Eslami.

The diagnostic framework can also foster constructive dialogue among stakeholders and ensure that adaptation efforts are both science-based and socially relevant.

title: H&M Foundation invests  9m on Bangladesh textile climate action
bodyText:
H&M Foundation has invested in Oporajita, which is a collaborative effort designed to empower women working in Bangladesh’s garment industry as it moves towards net-zero emissions.

The initiative, launched in 2022, involves various stakeholders, including non-governmental organisations, government representatives, and start-ups, aimed at providing women in the ready-made garment sector with essential skills and support networks.

The second phase of Oporajita, scheduled for 2025 to 2027, will emphasise climate adaptation and mitigation while maintaining a focus on the needs of female garment workers.

Priorities for Oporajita Phase II

This stage aims to future-proof factories and workers against climate disruptions by co-creating tools and guidance on climate adaptation and heat stress management. It will involve awareness training, risk assessments, and workplace measures in collaboration with factory managers and workers.

A key aspect involves deepening policy impact for a fair climate transition.

It includes advancing advocacy for policies that support decarbonisation, worker wellbeing, and an equitable transition through policy analysis, stakeholder dialogue, and targeted recommendations.

Moreover, efforts will centre on building a climate innovation ecosystem by supporting start-ups and innovators who are developing sustainable solutions for the ready-made garment (RMG) sector. The initiative intends to engage industry leaders in an investment network to scale impact and attract commercial capital.

Improving agency and wellbeing is another significant goal. The initiative plans to provide climate-resilient WASH facilities, accessible childcare, parenting support, and build financial and digital literacy among women.

Efforts will also be made to address gender-based violence and challenge norms that limit women s roles in technology and leadership.

Performance in Phase I

Oporajita reportedly made a tangible impact despite global challenges in its initial phase. The initiative enabled 1,416 women to secure future-facing roles in the circular economy, securing a 60% job placement rate and 13% average income growth.

Efforts to bolster leadership have resulted in over 16,000 women undergoing training tailored to address gender issues. Additionally, 60 female workers and community figures have been empowered to drive transformation within their factories and neighbourhoods.

The initiative also trained 1,628 out-of-work garment workers in entrepreneurship, with more than half starting their own businesses.

Furthermore, Oporajita facilitated the generation of nearly 500 new jobs in the sector and aided 20 start-ups. These enterprises focus on comprehensive strategies that enhance women’s job prospects, advocate for sustainable manufacturing practices, and reinforce the industry’s robustness.

H&M Foundation programme director Charlotte Brunnström said: Through Oporajita, we re not only responding to automation and climate risk, we re redefining who gets to lead the response. Women workers are often portrayed as vulnerable, but they are also solution-drivers. This phase is about giving them a seat at the table as the industry designs its net-zero future.

The implementing partners of Oporajita are Center for Communication Action Bangladesh (C-Cab), CARE Bangladesh, Build Bangladesh, Save the Children Bangladesh, LightCastle Partners, Swisscontact, WaterAid Bangladesh.

The programme draws insights from the “Just Climate Transitions in Bangladesh” report by consulting firm FSG, backed by the H&M Foundation and Laudes Foundation.

The report provides a systems-level framework for aligning climate goals with social protections in global supply chains.

In February this year, H&M Foundation agreed to join the Fashion ReModel, a demonstration project led by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, to advance the adoption of circular business model solutions for fashion.

title: Scotland-s rural heroes shortlisted for Helping It Happen 2025
bodyText:
Scotland-s rural champions are once again in the spotlight as the shortlist for the Helping It Happen Awards 2025 is unveiled.

Organised by Scottish Land & Estates and sponsored by NatureScot, the awards celebrate people and projects driving positive change in rural Scotland. With 11 categories spanning education, conservation, farming, tourism, and rural enterprise, the awards recognise the initiatives that strengthen the countryside.

The winners will be revealed at a celebratory event this autumn.

Ardnamurchan Estate supports local youth through whisky cask and education initiatives

The Working With Communities Award, sponsored by The Exiteers, honours individuals and groups improving everyday life in rural Scotland. Finalists include:

Ardnamurchan Estate/Ardnamurchan Trust: Supporting local youth by purchasing whisky casks at age 10, later funding education through buy-backs, encouraging young people to return with new skills. Arrochar Community Hydro: Launched in 2018 with land from Luss Estates, this hydroelectric project shares profits among Luss, Arrochar, and Tarbet, funding local initiatives. title: Startups in ClimateTech: Skytree Scientific Brings AI to Infrastructure Safety Planning
bodyText:
ASHEVILLE, NC - Skytree Scientific is revolutionizing the lightning protection industry with its AI-integrated platform, LRA Plus(TM), offering a transformative approach to infrastructure safety planning. In an era where climate change is intensifying weather phenomena, including increased lightning activity, the demand for advanced and efficient risk management solutions is more crucial than ever.



For decades, managing lightning risk has often been a complex and reactive process, relying on manual assessments and outdated information. However, the landscape is changing. Lightning is a powerful and often underestimated force, capable of inflicting catastrophic damage, disrupting operations, and causing significant financial losses, reaching billions of dollars annually in the US alone. Critical infrastructure, such as data centers, is particularly vulnerable, with downtime leading to substantial financial and reputational consequences. The increasing frequency and intensity of severe weather events linked to a changing climate further highlight the need for sophisticated protection strategies.

Skytree Scientific addresses these challenges head-on with LRA Plus, an AI-enhanced SaaS platform designed to streamline lightning risk assessments and enhance infrastructure resilience. The platform is built to empower engineers and organizations to proactively mitigate risks and safeguard critical infrastructure.

Key features and benefits of LRA Plus include:* Enhanced Speed and Efficiency: The platform delivers up to 90% faster completion times for lightning risk assessments by automating time-consuming manual calculation processes. * Advanced Automation: Sophisticated capabilities integrate high-fidelity data with analytical tools, replacing error-prone manual processes with precision-driven assessments. * Data-Driven Accuracy and Insights: LRA Plus delivers calculated understanding of specific facility risks, moving beyond assumptions to objective data. The system integrates extensive lightning strike data, including flash and strike-point density metrics (detailed measurements of lightning activity patterns), to provide accurate and current assessments. * Optimized Protection Strategies: AI analyzes lightning data and risk factors to offer tailored recommendations for protection strategies and identify high-risk areas. This ensures effective resource allocation, avoiding costs associated with both under-protection and over-spending. The platform facilitates scenario testing, such as evaluating Surge Protective Device (SPD) upgrades, optimizing protection design and strategy. * Automated Compliance: LRA Plus automates precise calculations required by international and regional standards including IEC 62305 and NFPA 780-2023 Annex L, providing confidence in compliance and strengthening insurer relationships. * Comprehensive Reporting and Support: The platform generates detailed, professional reports in over 57 languages. An AI-Powered Assistant simplifies assessment and compliance processes, offering instant guidance on standards and calculation explanations.

LRA Plus serves diverse markets including the lightning protection industry, electrical and consulting engineers, and Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) firms. The platform also provides value for renewable energy developers, transportation authorities, and government agencies seeking to protect valuable assets and ensure operational continuity.

The investment in AI-assisted lightning risk assessment offers a compelling return on investment (ROI), translating into saved time and resources, improved accuracy, optimized protection strategies, enhanced operational resilience, and direct mitigation of financial losses. Preventing even one instance of downtime can easily justify the investment. This approach aligns with the growing trend in ClimateTech where AI is seen as a critical enabler for climate adaptation and resilience, driving breakthroughs in managing climate impacts through data analysis and optimization.

By embracing advanced tools like LRA Plus, organizations can move confidently beyond guesswork, providing precise, reliable, and standards-compliant solutions to build a more resilient future in the face of a dynamic and growing threat.
